story:
Hey, I'm Danya (in case you didn't already know), and I've been accepted to go to Israel for ten days this summer on a Taglit-Birthright trip.

I'm Jewish, and I've always identified as a Jewish American. Though this is who I am, I am unsure as to what this really means history and culture-wise. I want to be more part of my religion and I want to see first hand what my people call their home land. That is why I applied for a Birthright trip.

Though the trip is mostly covered by Taglit-Birthright (flight from JFK to Israel and back, lodging, events and sightseeing, two meals a day...) there are some fees that are my responsibility. Things that are important like customary tipping of bus drivers and tour guides, that one meal a day that isn't included in the trip, and connecting flights.

I will be working until I leave to save money for this trip, but as a full time student I have to put my education first, making it slightly more difficult to work and save as much as I'd like to. I need seven hundred dollars, some of which I will be able to save for on my own, but not all of it.

I'm a political science major and an art minor.

This means that I'm constantly looking to view the world in new and interesting ways. In 2012 I fundraised and saved $2200 to go with my schools Spanish club to Ecuador. This trip opened my eyes to a world completely different from my own! This is something a possible future politician needs, because after all, they can't all be evil, and what way to better a person than to give them perspective?

If I go to Israel I won't only have a great time, but I'll also be furthering my education and working on bettering myself so that in the future I can work to better the world.

Though I am certain that you've already earned it some way, my eternal love will be given to anyone kind enough to support me and ANY contribution would be appreciated on a massive scale!

Lots of Love, Danya Nadel

story:
Please consider contributing to My Iman Montessori in the form of donations, volunteerism, or other gifts

Because MIM is a private, independent institution, we do not receive support from the public. Our school's daily operation is run on tuition costs and donations. 

Our community has been fortunate enough to begin and maintain a full-time Islamic school that provides a wonderful, enriching environment for our next generation of Muslim children to flourish as educated Mu'mineen. SubhanAllah, since MIM's inception in 2009, we've grown to consist of a diverse student population from all over the world. With this diversity and growing enrollment numbers come specific obligations from our community to help support our school's mission and continue to provide quality education in a modest Islamic environment. This presents us with the opportunity to give Sadaqah Jariah (voluntary charity).

Please check out our video on Animoto.
http://animoto.com/play/h481KXyGmRDCQO3XKCjFWQ

Where does my contribution go?

Each year, we designate a certain amount of money to each of our fundraising projects to help better our school. Ongoing fundraising categories include the following:

  • Tuition: A significant portion of monetary gifts goes towards helping families with tuition who are not able to afford it in full.
  • Materials: As each of our students is unique and talented, donations allow us to purchase materials which will help expand, enrich, and challenge each of those children.
  • Facility: We are a growing school Alhamdulillah! Your donations make it possible for our school to not only expand in number of students, but in size, too!

story:
Oplerno is an Open Learning Organization—a global higher education movement for the 21st Century. Over the past six months we have built most of our technological infrastructure, recruited over 50 faculty from all over the world, developed a sustainable and profitable business plan and applied for approval to operate from the State of Vermont. We are launching this campaign to raise capital to take our organization to the next level and launch a platform in higher education that will lower costs for students, increase faculty pay and make access to small class size personal education a reality for everyone on the planet.  We also want to pay our staff for their hard work and dedication, and get our technological infrastructure up and running on secure servers.  We want you to found (and fund) Oplerno with us.

Featured On:

 






1% for Change

Our campaign is a little different. Besides the perks listed on the right we make this promise: for every $100,000 we raise, Oplerno will donate 1% of our net profits—forever—to  fund educational, economic development, health and ecological projects. (We will make this commitment up to $1,000,000 or 10% of our net profits forever.) Your gift will not only fund our work, but it could also form the foundation for funding other change projects in the future.

The Basics

Oplerno is built upon empowering faculty and students.

·  Faculty own their courses, control the content and teaching approach, and earn at least 80% of the tuition they generate per student. Most importantly, they set the price of their class. We expect faculty will earn on average between $4,000 and $12,000 per 12-week class.

·  Students choose their courses based on content area, skills offered, faculty experience/reviews and cost. Most courses will cost between $500 and $1,500 per 12-week, 3-credit class.

·  Our infrastructure can be accessed using a smart phone or tablet enabling greater worldwide accessibility. If you have cell service you can access Oplerno.

·  “The Marketplace” is a proprietary dynamic sortable and searchable software system that creates an educational exchange where students find the courses and teachers that will meet their needs.

·  “Skills Portfolio” is a proprietary software program that offers another way to evaluate and document students' achievements and skills acquisition. This is used in addition to traditional grades and transcripts.

Perks

Our perks reflect our grassroots movement and hand-built customized approach to education.  Take home a beautiful desk by Vermont woodworker Eli Jager crafted out of beautiful, sustainably harvested white oak, or some world-famous Vermont maple syrup.  We also offer ways for you to display your support of the movement and redesign of higher education.  Grab a T-shirt, sticker, or even a program or college within Oplerno!  All of these are great ways to show that you support empowering great teachers, decreasing the burden of student loans, and stepping into the new way that education will be experienced.  And it wouldn’t be a true grassroots movement if we didn’t remind you that every dollar counts and helps us reach our campaign goal, so please give what you can!

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will still use our funds in the ways we described above (paying staff, launching our technological infrastructure on secure servers, helping get us toward accreditation).  We want to get this project operationalized and start allowing faculty members to teach for their fair share and for students to access high-quality education at a reasonable cost!

Below is the print being offered by photographer Michael Everett (www.everettvideo.com).  It represents Oplerno's mission of building a boat and setting out on our journey to reach the corners of the globe with access to high quality higher education:


We are all Founders

In coming up with an idea, building the foundation and creating a team is the first part of founding a new kind of educational institution. However, the real founding happens when people take ownership and build something greater than ourselves.  If you can spread the word, donate some money, or build a course then you are a founder. Oplerno is an Open Learning Organization designed to create a new kind of higher education. During this campaign, anyone who donates money, signs up to be a faculty member, or spreads the word is a founder and we will list them as such on our website forever. Let's get the change started!

About Us

Oplerno is a group of practitioners, teachers, staff members, advisors, and technological gurus.  We have three staff members, 50 faculty members (so far, and are always recruiting more!), and a strong team of advisors to help us on our quest.  Our staff has started schools, built software and houses, taught in all levels of education, and are ready for a change for students and faculty alike.  Our faculty are rocket scientists (really!), lawyers, educators, doctors, and passionate experts in their fields.  Our advisors should make any startup envious, as we have recruited a group with great energy, vast knowledge and experience, and a genuine support for Oplerno’s mission.

Find Out More

We have an extensive and very detailed website located at Oplerno.com. There is a lot of information on our operations including where our faculty are in the world and what they teach. You can also access a FAQ page at http://oplerno.com/faq/.

Voiceover by Liz Regan of The Color Machine (www.thecolormachine.com)
Music by (Ben Whalen is) Sugarbeard  

Founder T-Shirt

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Anna Westbrook and I have ten years of experience in educational children's programming. I have been traveling to Haiti and the Dominican Republic for seven years to live, work, and study Dominican-Haitian Relations. I am a music major and a dance minor and I teach piano lessons at several locations near my hometown of New London, CT, including at a primarily Haitian community.
  • I will be teaching music and dance lessons in an orphanage in Haiti run by Love in Motion, a Monadnock Bible Conference Ministry. See their website here: http://www.monadnockbible.org/haiti/
  • I believe teaching music is my way of making a lasting difference on the lives of the children in this orphanage. By contributing, you will be supporting the personal growth of the students in the orphanage. Music helps people, and learning to make music is one of the most empowering things we can teach someone. Please join with me in empowering these kids. 

What I Need & What You Get

I need help physically getting there:

  • I am requesting $1000 for travel costs. The orphanage is providing me room and board in exchange for the amount of time and effort I am putting into preparing for and executing this project. I expect to pay $400-$600 on plane tickets, $80-200 on bus fare, and $120-200 on water and other necessities. Any extra funding will be reserved for emergency travel needs until the end of my trip, at which point it will be donated to the orphanage.
  • Perks for supporting me range from thank you notes to coffee dates, and every person who donates will be given a copy of my financial records after the trip. 
  • If I don't reach my entire goal, I will put the money I receive towards a plane ticket and find another way to supplement my funding. Regardless of whether I reach my full goal, I am going on this trip.

Where My Heart Is At

I've learned a lot over the seven years I've been volunteering in Haiti. If you want to understand my mind and hear my heart, read some of what I've written:

  • I wrote lesson plans on Dominican-Haitian Relations that were published by NYU:  http://clacs.as.nyu.edu/object/clacs.k12outreac...
  • Here is a blog post I wrote on how I stopped thinking of myself as "saving" anyone while volunteering: http://newlondon.patch.com/groups/anna-westbroo...

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? No Worries. Here's how you can help:

  • Spread the word! Tell anyone who you think might be interested in the project. 
  • Pray! I think people of all spiritual and religious backgrounds (or lack thereof) can relate to my goals in Haiti. However, since I am a Christian, I will specifically ask my brothers and sisters in Christ to pray for me and for the orphanage I will be working at, because Jesus is the one who turns the good things we dream up into reality.

story:
First of all, we would like to thank the donators who have helped us reach our target in just a few days!!! To encourage more givers, we’ve raised the bar and added 2 challenges!

Here’s the story…

Once upon a time, the French brethren on the Plateau where we live went to the meetings whatever the weather and by all means...

As we are just over 1000 meters in altitude, there is usually a lot of snow in the winter. In order to reach the bible reading meetings in Les Chalayes, walking wouldn’t have been the easiest or fastest…. they then needed other means to get there…On skis!

Now we want to show how we are all very thankful that they maintained the position up until now, so...

THE CHALLENGE

On the 4th of October, we will go from Cabasse to Les Chalayes, the same path our grandparents used to take, a beautiful walk through forest and mountainous countryside on skis, carrying sedan chairs or wearing clogs all the way...

But the challenge is this... We rarely have snow in October; this means we have a 99% chance of 'skiing' on grass/rocks/mud! This will be difficult!

You may think there is no point in doing this, or that it's a crazy idea, but actually there is a point. The education of our children!  We hope you’ll motivate us through a donation to our school ‘Les Cardamines’ in Le Chambon...

Here are the different challenges:

Challenge 1: The Clogers!

A 14 km (9 miles) walk with wood and leather clogs!!!

Challenge 2: The Carriers!

A 5 km (3 miles) walk carrying a sedan chair!!! 4 carriers and one “carried” …

Challenge 3: The Skiers!

A 5 km (3 miles) ride with old wooden skis!!!

We believe in our school and are not only going to do this for fun.  As everyone knows our schools and schooling are exceptionally important so that our children can have the best education possible.  They deserve only the best.  To guarantee this, your donation is highly needed!

I am sure we are going to discover that it's a lot harder than we first thought. Most of the way it is flat and for those who have tried skiing, you'll know that it's not easy to walk with ski boots, especially on grass and rocks!

We don't think of donations as large or small, but each donation as a step forward in securing our children’s education at Les Cardamines. We need your help!

Sad that you can’t see this live? Stay connected…  We’ll keep you posted with lots of photos and videos :)

Thank you very much for your support,

story:
Hello Supporters

Our names are Missionary Patricia Trotman, & Missionary Grace Eiland. This will be our first visit to Africa.  

We are members of Strictly Biblical Bible Teaching Ministry and part of

 Strictly Biblical's International Ministry (S.I.M.). We have been supporting two churches in Africa for over 2 years.

The first one is "Christian Revival Ministry"  in  Evaton, South Africa, where we are helping a HIV orphanage and feeding program.

The second one is "Missions Nation Orphanage" in Lusaka, Zambia where we also support an orphanage of 150 children. 

We are going to Zambia to assess the needs of the children, people and to help spread the gospel.

In supporting this mission, you will be helping us:

  • With our tickets and accommodations
  • Feeding & clothing 
  • Education of the children
  • Medical help
  • Providing bibles and other needs

The mission of S.I.M.  is our passion,

We pray that you will join us in our vision. 


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need  $8,500.00  to help make this mission a success. We have been doing fund raisers at our church to help fund the trip.
  • The target date for the trip is September, 2014.
  • For a donation of $10.00 you will receive a picture of the children
  • For a donation of $25.00 you will receive a Comfort Bear 
  • For a donation of $50.00 or more you will receive a T-Shirt and a Comfort Bear with "I Support Strictly's International Ministry" inscribed on it.
 

Comfort Bears are donated by Gary Wachler of David Wachler & Sons , 100 S. Old Woodward, Birmingham, MI 48009, 248-540-4622 

Comfort Bears For Kids are donated to bring comfort to children who are going through a difficult and frightening time in their lives.

Comfort Bears for Kids will also be donating Comfort Bears to take to Africa for the children

 

The Impact

Is to see this ministry grow and to expand to other parts of the world. We see a vision of planting churches, digging wells for water and helping in places such as India, China, Haiti etc. Your donations will be supporting  food, education, clothing and giving medical assistance to thousands. Every little bit counts.   

Your contribution is VERY important to us. This is truly a call of Christ.  

(Matt. 25: 35-40).

 Will you please support this ministry? 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean that you can’t help:

  • Ask others to get the word out and make some noise about S.I.M. (strictly international ministry) campaign.
  •  Use the IndieGoGo share tools!
  • Another way to donate is to send a check or money order to: Strictly Biblical Bible Teaching Ministries Church at 10709 Grand River Detroit, Michigan 48204 and write for Strictly International Ministry or S. I. M. on the check or Money order.
  • And most of all PRAYER! Please keep us in your prayers!
God Bless You!

L.N.C. (love in Christ) Patricia & Grace

story:
Summary

Over a dozen contingent faculty members working in women’s and gender studies and related disciplines have organized three conference sessions on the theme of contingent labor in academia for the National Women’s Studies Association’s 2014 annual conference.  Five participants did not receive enough funding from either their respective institutions or the NWSA to attend.

You might be asking - what is a contingent faculty member? Contingent faculty member is a term for anyone who is not a full-time, permanent member of faculty (tenure track or otherwise) at a college or university. This includes adjunct professors, part (and often full-) time lecturers, visiting professors, post-doctorates, and some staff members. Contingent faculty very often earn less than a living wage with little to no benefits, and currently make up over 75% of the professoriate.

Now you might be saying, but what does this have to do with women’s and gender studies? First, women comprise a majority of this precarious workforce, and many are women of color, in disciplines in the humanities and social sciences that have historically contributed, and continue to contribute, to women and gender studies departments and that, like WGS, are marginalized within academia.  Second, as a discipline, women's and gender studies is grounded in social justice and includes deep analysis of structural issues like racism, sexism, and classism (and their intersections). Because the problems faced by contingent faculty are structural - that is, they are both caused by and indicative of a deeply inequitable system -  those working in women's and gender studies are well positioned to contribute to conversations examining the problem and its solutions. And finally, these sessions mark a watershed moment for the field, as they will be the first coordinated attempt to address the issue of contingent labor during an annual conference. With the acceptance of three roundtable sessions on contingency, NWSA has shown support for the work that needs to be done to address working conditions in higher education. We need your help to match that support with funding.


What We Need

Contingent faculty have been, and continue to be, left out of professional development opportunities because of lack of support from the colleges, universities, and associations of which they are faculty and members, including the funds to attend conferences.  Although all of our participants applied for funding from the NWSA and their institutions (where possible), five participants were not able to access enough funding to attend the conference.

  • Money raised will help five contingent faculty members attend the NWSA. Members have all already been accepted as participants in the conference, and have registered.

  • Additional money will be donated first to contingent faculty and other precariously employed individuals who have also been accepted to the conference, but did not receive sufficient funding, either from the NWSA or their employers.

  • Any further additional money will be donated to the NWSA for the creation of a fund to support contingent faculty travel expenses for future conferences, directly addressing the increasingly precarious nature of our profession.


The Impact

By supporting contingent faculty members, you will enable our roundtable participants to contribute to the first multi-session discussion on the theme of contingent labor at an NWSA conference. The roundtable participants are eager to collaborate with conference attendees - not only to make contingent faculty’s voices heard, but also to outline some concrete steps that NWSA members can take to address these issues in women’s and gender studies departments and programs around the country.  

We anticipate that outcomes of these initial efforts (including this fundraising effort!) will help to ensure that conversations about the future of women’s and gender studies include *all* members of this diverse and ever-expanding discipline for years to come.   

Details, Details

$500 per person ($2500 total) will get our remaining five participants to the conference. We know we can reach this goal with your help...and we think we can raise even more! Every dollar we raise over $2500 will be distributed to other contingent faculty members and precariously employed individuals who do not have sufficient funding to attend the NWSA conference. Any additional funds raised will be donated directly to NWSA to create a fund for contingent faculty to attend future conferences.

Other Ways to Help

  • Even if you can't donate to the campaign, you can still support us. Ask folks to get the word out: share it on Twitter, Facebook, Tumblr, and the rest of the usual suspects.
  • Contact one of the organizers and donate a "perk" to the campaign.
  • Get more information on women & contingency in higher ed through the New Faculty Majority Women & Contingency Project:  http://www.newfacultymajority.info/women-and-co...
  • Support research & advocacy efforts regarding contingent faculty in your discipline, at your university, and beyond!
story_txt:
Summary Over a dozen contingent faculty members working in women’s and gender studies and related disciplines have organized three conference sessions on the theme of contingent labor in academia for the National Women’s Studies Association’s 2014 annual conference.  Five participants did not receive enough funding from either their respective institutions or the NWSA to attend. You might be asking - what is a contingent faculty member? Contingent faculty member is a term for anyone who is not a full-time, permanent member of faculty (tenure track or otherwise) at a college or university. This includes adjunct professors, part (and often full-) time lecturers, visiting professors, post-doctorates, and some staff members. Contingent faculty very often earn less than a living wage with little to no benefits, and currently make up over 75% of the professoriate. Now you might be saying, but what does this have to do with women’s and gender studies? First, women comprise a majority of this precarious workforce, and many are women of color, in disciplines in the humanities and social sciences that have historically contributed, and continue to contribute, to women and gender studies departments and that, like WGS, are marginalized within academia.  Second, as a discipline, women's and gender studies is grounded in social justice and includes deep analysis of structural issues like racism, sexism, and classism (and their intersections). Because the problems faced by contingent faculty are structural - that is, they are both caused by and indicative of a deeply inequitable system -  those working in women's and gender studies are well positioned to contribute to conversations examining the problem and its solutions. And finally, these sessions mark a watershed moment for the field, as they will be the first coordinated attempt to address the issue of contingent labor during an annual conference. With the acceptance of three roundtable sessions on contingency, NWSA has shown support for the work that needs to be done to address working conditions in higher education. We need your help to match that support with funding.What We NeedContingent faculty have been, and continue to be, left out of professional development opportunities because of lack of support from the colleges, universities, and associations of which they are faculty and members, including the funds to attend conferences.  Although all of our participants applied for funding from the NWSA and their institutions (where possible), five participants were not able to access enough funding to attend the conference.
Money raised will help five contingent faculty members attend the NWSA. Members have all already been accepted as participants in the conference, and have registered. 
Additional money will be donated first to contingent faculty and other precariously employed individuals who have also been accepted to the conference, but did not receive sufficient funding, either from the NWSA or their employers. 
Any further additional money will be donated to the NWSA for the creation of a fund to support contingent faculty travel expenses for future conferences, directly addressing the increasingly precarious nature of our profession. 
The ImpactBy supporting contingent faculty members, you will enable our roundtable participants to contribute to the first multi-session discussion on the theme of contingent labor at an NWSA conference. The roundtable participants are eager to collaborate with conference attendees - not only to make contingent faculty’s voices heard, but also to outline some concrete steps that NWSA members can take to address these issues in women’s and gender studies departments and programs around the country.  We anticipate that outcomes of these initial efforts (including this fundraising effort!) will help to ensure that conversations about the future of women’s and gender studies include *all* members of this diverse and ever-expanding discipline for years to come.    Details, Details$500 per person ($2500 total) will get our remaining five participants to the conference. We know we can reach this goal with your help...and we think we can raise even more! Every dollar we raise over $2500 will be distributed to other contingent faculty members and precariously employed individuals who do not have sufficient funding to attend the NWSA conference. Any additional funds raised will be donated directly to NWSA to create a fund for contingent faculty to attend future conferences. Other Ways to Help 
Even if you can't donate to the campaign, you can still support us. Ask folks to get the word out: share it on Twitter, Facebook, Tumblr, and the rest of the usual suspects.
Contact one of the organizers and donate a "perk" to the campaign.

story:
The GMS was launched with the fundamental goal to develop music education, promote music appreciation, to introduce music as a tool for creative free expression and to the improvement of the creative potential of children in Gaza though music. The GMS has since been a place where musically talented children (aged 7-16) are incubated, where they learn the joy of music, and share it with their community. The School has also opened opportunities for children’s talents and skills to grow and be exposed to a variety of cultures through the international language of music.

The school opens opportunities for musically talented children, ages 7-16, to learn the joy of music, and share it with their community.  About 185 students are currently enrolled in the school’s regular program, which offers lessons for seven instruments: oud, violin, piano, guitar, qanun, trumpet, and cello.

The Gaza Music School contributes to filling in the huge gap of music teaching in schools    and among children and youth in Gaza where arts courses in general and music in particular have been constantly negligencted in Palestinian schools  generally. Arts centres in Gaza  are either inexistnet or lack the specialized cadre, let alone discouragement from the schools or families for their children to get enrolled in such creative fields.This project is a challenge to the imposed closures and state of isolation as well as a challenge to social hindrances since it involves equally male and female students.

 In Gaza Strip , closures, isolation and fragmentation imposed by Israel, are negatively affecting all forms of Palestinians’ daily life. This project contributes to activating cultural life, enabling the ESNCM to expand its academic and non-academic programs in order to reach a wider range of the society to learn and enjoy music, promoting music and musicians, and enhancing internal and international exchange. Such activities have a great influence to elevate people’s hope, resilience, perseverance and steadfastness amid all daily encounters of despair and frustration.

The A.M. Qattan Foundation Launched the Gaza Music School (GMS) project in July 2008, in response to growing demand for music education in the Gaza Strip.  GMS started as a three-year pilot project with co-funding partnership from the Swedish International Development Agency.  It offers the first-ever structured and long-term music education programme in Gaza.  While the ESNCM gave it’s technical and academic support helping the school management to establish its curricular and academic set up.

In January 2009, GMS was destroyed during the Israeli war on Gaza.  In recognition of the vitality of the GMS to the social, psychological, and artistic development of children – and against tremendous odds – the A.  M.  Qattan Foundation re-opened the School three months later in a new expanded space, and adding to the team to accommodate the growing number of students.  Support of the reopening effort came from individuals and institutions locally and from Sweden, Norway, the UK, Germany, France and the USA. 

Following an agreement between the Edward Said National Conservatory of Music and the Qattan Foundation, the GazaMusicSchool was handed to the ESNCM on April 1st 2012, therefore becoming the Conservatory’s fifth branch in Palestine. The ESNCM is now responsible for the school’s financial, academic and administrative issues. 

WATCH the Audio Slideshow on GazaMusicSchool at the blow link

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-13035704

story:
Overview

Sky Candy has been teaching classes and creating innovative aerial theate since 2010.  As we grow and become an increasingly busy and established group, it's key that we foster growth and opportunities in our teacher group, as well as connect with the greater aerial and circus arts community.

In February 2013, the New England Center for Circus Arts will be teaching the introductory and foundational classes for their Nimble Arts Teacher Certification Course.  This course is one of the country's first and only aerial arts teaching certification programs.

Funding Teacher Training

Three of our teachers - Bethany, Joanna and Winnie - will be headed up to Vermont from February 17 - 24 for this intensive one week program.  In addition to missing out on a week of teaching classes and hosting open studios (the primary income source for all three of these folks), the trio will largely be funding this trip, including all program expenses on their own.  Here's the breakdown of what we're looking at:

UPDATED: Jan 12, 2013

  • NECCA Course Fees: $3375 
  • Air Travel: $900
  • Lodging & Local Transport: $390 (thanks, Julia L!)
  • TOTAL: $4665

This campaign is set at a goal of $1500 to help Bethany, Joanna and Winnie defray some of costs of this trip, which will hope will provide a great benefit to our local aerial community and its student body.  We hope that providing more opportunities to train and learn outside of our studio will help bring a higher level of professionalism and expertise to our already amazing teacher's group! 

Support this campaign and we've got loads of prizes for you including Sky Candy classes, private lessons, tee-shirts, invite to an exclusive send-off party, and more!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, it's totally cool!  We will love you loads and hope that you can help us out by sharing this campaign with your friends.

Also, check out some sweet Sky Candy shots from the amazing Hammondovi (psst, he took the photo at the top of this page!).  You can order ones you really love as prints, tote bags, calendars and water bottles.  Geoff is generously donating the profits from these photos to our teachers for the trip.

So yes, you can in fact own a stainless steel water bottle with Bethany, Winnie, or Joanna on it. Seriously, do it!

story:
The Pitch:

A talented young woman from Minneapoliis needs our help badly.  She is a brilliant young artist who will someday write the best stories ever for film and television. 

This Fall she started college, in Boston.  It was her dream to go there and she nearly expired in her efforts to make it  academically and especially financially.

Our artist comes from a very poor family, both her mother and father have been chronically unemployed due to the crippling effects of the New Depression.  They can not make their payment to the school for the very small amount of tuition they are asked to contribute.

We are asking for enough money to pay our young artist's tuition for one semester.  She herself has already saved and worked to find half, out of sheer determination and will, but the rest remains horribly, tragically unattainable.

We are not asking for pizza and latte money here, the poor child already works two jobs ...  and that's during the school year ...

You Can Make a Difference

Please donate a few dollars, more if you possibly can, it really won't take much to make this happen.  Just a few drops in the bucket...

Oh, one more thing.  The title of this campaign "And Then I Started Crying" is the title of her first novel, a retrospective on growing up in a post-modern bohemian family.  Dysfunction is guaranteed.

Gratefully,

Your Friends in Minneapolis

story:
My name is Jordi Harris, and I am a 17 year old living in Gisborne, New Zealand. I have been accepted into the Cromwell College Apartments and outdoor pursuits programme in Central Otago in the South Island for my final year of school in 2015. I am really lucky to be accepted into this school and feel very excited to have this chance. There are no colleges that offer outdoor pursuits in our area and I would have to travel away from my home to make this dream a reality. I believe that if I was able to attend this college it will open up lots of opportunities; not only for me but for the Gisborne community as I would like to one day offer experiences like this to students from our region. We have so many amazing, natural landmarks and awesome locations in this area that would perfect for Outdoor education.

Cromwell College is going to cost around over $17,000 for the year. I plan to work full time over summer to earn as much as possible, work part time during the year and dedicate my holidays to making extra money. My parents are also prepared to take additional jobs to help me do what I love!

story:
Platon vous en dira plus sur Platosphere

 IN ENGLISH!

 

Qui suis-je?

Christian Keime, lorrain de souche, marseillais d'adoption. Naguère palefrenier, cavalier, enseignant, éditeur et musicien, j'étudie les dialogues de Platon depuis plusieurs années. Aujourd'hui, j'expérimente une nouvelle manière de parler de philosophie antique en donnant des conférences publiques ouvertes à tous, en construisant un site internet et en enregistrant des émissions sur Platon destinées aux enfants. En savoir plus?

 

Où vais-je?

J’ai été admis en doctorat à Cambridge à partir de janvier 2015. Je veux écrire une thèse qui montre que Le Banquet de Platon donne des leçons pratiques et modernes de communication et de pédagogie.

En savoir plus sur mon projet de thèse?

Scène de banquet, fresque de Paestum, vers 500 av. J.-C.


Pourquoi Cambridge?

Cambridge est le lieu idéal pour mener à bien une étude interdisciplinaire comme la mienne, à la croisée de la littérature, de la philosophie et des théories de la communication. C'est aussi dans cette université que j'ai rencontré le plus grand nombre de spécialistes du Banquet de Platon.

Au terme de trois ans de thèse, j'effectuerai trois voyages d'études en Allemagne et aux Etats-Unis pour travailler avec d'autres spécialistes de Platon. 


Et pourquoi une thèse?

  • Pour pousser plus loin ma recherche à l’université : je chercherai des leçons de communication et de pédagogie dans d’autres dialogues de Platon et chez d’autres auteurs.
    
        
  • Pour transmettre à un large public le résultat de ma recherche : aux étudiants ainsi qu’aux non spécialistes curieux de philosophie et d’Antiquité. Un diplôme de Cambridge donnera de l’autorité à une démarche pédagogique atypique que j’engage aujourd’hui dans le cadre de ma campagne.

            Raphaël, L'Ecole d'Athènes, vers 1510.


Soutenez-moi, Platon vous le rendra!

Pour présenter mon projet et remercier les donateurs, je propose des conférences sur Platon ouvertes à tous, en particulier à ceux qui craignent les conférences de philosophie ancienne ! Voir les prochaines dates ?

Dans le même esprit, le site internet Platosphère présente Platon à différents types de public. Si je peux poursuivre mon travail, ce site sera demain un lieu d’information et d’échange privilégié sur Platon : il fournira des informations sur l’actualité de la recherche, des outils d’analyse pour les étudiants, et tout le monde y apprendra que Platon est lisible, souvent drôle, et qu’il sait même parler aux enfants du XXIe siècle.

Envoyez un palefrenier à l’université : vous ferez entrer Platon dans la cité!

Théodore Géricault, Course de chevaux libres, 1817. 


Où ira votre argent?

Coût total de la première année d’étude à Cambridge :

inscription (36%), logement (27%) et dépenses courantes (37%)

 

25 000 €

 

Déjà financé (travaux d’édition) :

 

17 000 €

Reste à financer :

8 000 €

Est-ce bien réaliste ?

Oui! Si je parviens à réunir 8000 € pour la première année, je pourrai financer plus facilement les années suivantes :

  • grâce à mon expérience du crowdfunding, j’organiserai une campagne plus efficace l’année prochaine,

  • grâce à votre soutien, mon projet sera plus crédible auprès d’autres mécènes, en particulier les entreprises et les fondations privées,

  • en étudiant à Cambridge, je trouverai plus facilement qu’en France des opportunités de travail, en particulier pendant les vacances : cours privés ou "summer schools".


Comment m’aider ?

Vous pouvez m’aider même sans argent. Parlez du projet autour de vous et communiquez sur les réseaux sociaux :

  • en partageant cette page sur Facebook, Twitter et Google+ (voir les onglets de partage en haut de  page),

  • en partageant Platosphere sur les réseaux sociaux,

  • en likant ma page

     Facebook.


Merci, déjà ...

au chœur Filigrane, à Albert, Almut, Anne, Elsa, Emmanuelle, Guy, Marie Annick, Maximilien, Moritz, Ragip, Sandy et Véronique pour leur participation enjouée à l’enregistrement du pitch. Merci à Elizabeth pour sa relecture généreuse du texte. Merci à David pour tout le reste, et plus encore!



SEND A STABLE-LAD TO CAMBRIDGE


Help Christian finance his first year at Cambridge: he will bring Plato to the street!


Plato will tell you more about it on Platosphere

 EN FRANÇAIS!


Who am I?

Christian Keime, born in the East of France, living in Marseille. Working for several years as a stable-lad, a rider, a teacher, a publisher and a musician, I kept studying Plato's dialogues. Today, I take part in academic gatherings and am experimenting a new way of presenting Plato to the general public, by giving conferences, building a website, and making a broadcast: "Plato talks to the kids". Learn more about me ?

Where am I heading for?

I have been admitted to Cambridge (UK) for a three-year PhD program starting in January 2015. In my thesis, I want to show that Plato’s Symposium delivers lessons in communication and pedagogy.

Learn more about my thesis project?

Symposium scene, Paestum, Italy, around 500 B. C. E.


Why Cambridge?

Today, Cambridge University is the best place to carry out such an interdisciplinary study that spans philosophy, literature and communication theory. It is also the place where I have met the largest number of scholars working on Plato’s Symposium.

At the end of my PhD, I have planned three study trips to Germany and the United-States in order to work with other Plato specialists.


And why a PhD?

  •  To carry on with my research on communication at university: I wish to investigate other Platonic dialogues and other authors.

            

       

  •  To communicate my research to a broad audience: both students and anyone interested in Antiquity and philosophy. A doctorate from Cambridge will give credibility and authority to my current educational action.

           Raphael, The School of Athens, around 1510. 


Support me, Platosphere will thank you!

In order to present my project and to thank the generous donors, I am now giving conferences on Plato and introducing Plato to everyone through a website: “Platosphere”. Tomorrow, if I can carry on with my work, Platosphere could be a bilingual reference website on Plato, helping both scholars and students, and also presenting Plato to non specialists in layman’s terms. Then you will realise that Plato is accessible, often witty, and that he even knows how to speak to kids.

Send a stable-lad off to university: you will bring Plato into the marketplace!

Théodore Géricault, The Race of the Riderless Horses, 1817.


Where does your money go?

Cost of the first year of PhD studies at Cambridge:

university fees (36%), accommodation (27%), and maintenance (37%)

 

25 000 €

Already funded (publishing):

17 000 €

Remaining gap :

8 000 €

Risks and challenges

A lot of money needs to be raised. But it's possible! If I can finance my first year of studies, it will be easier to fund the remaining ones:
  • thanks to your support, more donors will trust my project, particularly private companies and foundations.
  • thanks to my experience of crowdfunding, next year I'll be able to launch a more successful campaign.
  • many job opportunities are offered to Cambridge students, particularly during holidays.


Other ways you can help

There are other ways to help besides monetary donations: spread the word! 
  • Share this page on Facebook, Twitter and Google+ (see top of page),
  • Share Platosphere on social networks,
  • Like my Facebook page.

Thanks, already...

to the Filigrane Choir, to Albert, Almut, Anne, Elsa, Emmanuelle, Guy, Marie Annick, Maximilien, Moritz, Ragip, Sandy et Véronique for talking and singing so cheerfully in the pitch. Thanks to Elizabeth, for reviewing this text so generously. Thanks to David for everything, and even more!


 EN FRANÇAIS!

Scène de banquet, fresque de Paestum, vers 500 av. J.-C.



Pourquoi Cambridge?
Cambridge est le lieu idéal pour mener à bien une étude interdisciplinaire comme la mienne, à la croisée de la littérature, de la philosophie et des théories de la communication. C'est aussi dans cette université que j'ai rencontré le plus grand nombre de spécialistes du Banquet de Platon.
Au terme de trois ans de thèse, j'effectuerai trois voyages d'études en Allemagne et aux Etats-Unis pour travailler avec d'autres spécialistes de Platon. 

Et pourquoi une thèse?




Pour pousser plus loin ma recherche à l’université : je
chercherai des leçons de communication et de pédagogie dans d’autres dialogues
de Platon et chez d’autres auteurs.



    




        


Pour transmettre à un large public le résultat de ma recherche : aux étudiants ainsi qu’aux non spécialistes curieux de philosophie et d’Antiquité. Un diplôme de Cambridge donnera de l’autorité à une démarche pédagogique atypique que j’engage aujourd’hui dans le cadre de ma campagne.




            Raphaël, L'Ecole d'Athènes, vers 1510.


Soutenez-moi, Platon vous le rendra!



Pour présenter mon projet et remercier les donateurs, je propose
des conférences sur Platon ouvertes à tous, en particulier à ceux qui craignent les conférences de philosophie ancienne ! Voir les prochaines dates ?
Dans le même esprit, le site internet Platosphère présente Platon à différents types de public. Si je peux poursuivre mon
travail, ce site sera demain un lieu d’information et d’échange
privilégié sur Platon : il fournira des informations sur l’actualité de la
recherche, des outils d’analyse pour les étudiants, et tout le monde y apprendra
que Platon est lisible, souvent drôle, et qu’il sait même parler aux enfants du
XXIe siècle.
Envoyez un palefrenier à l’université : vous ferez entrer Platon dans la cité!



Théodore Géricault, Course de chevaux libres, 1817. 



Où ira votre argent?




Coût total de la première année d’étude à
  Cambridge :
inscription (36%), logement (27%) et dépenses courantes
  (37%)
 


25 000 €
 




Déjà financé (travaux
  d’édition) :
 


17 000 €




Reste à
  financer :


8 000 €




Est-ce bien
réaliste ?


Oui! Si je parviens à réunir 8000 € pour la première année, je
pourrai financer plus facilement les années suivantes :





grâce à mon expérience du crowdfunding, j’organiserai une
campagne plus efficace l’année prochaine,



grâce à votre soutien, mon projet sera plus crédible auprès
d’autres mécènes, en particulier les entreprises et les fondations privées,



en étudiant à Cambridge, je trouverai plus facilement
qu’en France des opportunités de travail, en particulier pendant les
vacances : cours privés ou "summer schools".




Comment m’aider ?
Vous pouvez m’aider même
sans argent. Parlez du projet autour de vous et communiquez sur les
réseaux sociaux :

en partageant cette page sur Facebook, Twitter et Google+ (voir les onglets de partage en haut de  page),
en partageant Platosphere sur les réseaux sociaux,

en likant ma page

 Facebook.







Merci, déjà ...


au chœur Filigrane,
à Albert, Almut, Anne, Elsa, Emmanuelle, Guy, Marie Annick, Maximilien, Moritz,
Ragip, Sandy et Véronique pour leur participation enjouée à l’enregistrement du
pitch. Merci à Elizabeth pour sa relecture généreuse du texte. Merci à David pour tout le reste, et plus encore!




SEND A STABLE-LAD TO CAMBRIDGE





Help Christian finance his first year at Cambridge: he will bring Plato to the street!


Plato will tell you more about it on Platosphere




 EN FRANÇAIS!
Who am I?





Christian Keime, born in the East of France, living in
  Marseille. Working for several years as a stable-lad, a rider, a teacher, a
  publisher and a musician, I kept studying Plato's dialogues. Today, I take part in academic gatherings and am experimenting a new way of
  presenting Plato to the general public, by giving conferences, building a
  website, and making a broadcast: "Plato talks to the kids". Learn more about me ?






Where am I heading for?
I have been
admitted to Cambridge (UK) for a three-year PhD program starting in January 2015. In my thesis, I
want to show that Plato’s Symposium delivers lessons in communication and pedagogy.



Learn more about my thesis project?






Symposium scene, Paestum, Italy, around 500 B. C. E.



Why Cambridge?
Today,
Cambridge University is the best place to carry out such an interdisciplinary study that spans philosophy, literature and communication theory. It is also the place
where I have met the largest number of scholars working on Plato’s Symposium. 
At the end
of my PhD, I have planned three study
trips to Germany and the United-States in order to work with other Plato specialists.

And why a PhD?






 To carry on with my research on communication at university: I wish to investigate other Platonic dialogues and other authors.




            






       





 To communicate my research to a broad audience: both students and anyone interested in Antiquity and philosophy. A doctorate from Cambridge will give credibility and authority to my current educational action.





           Raphael, The School of Athens, around 1510. 



Support me, Platosphere will thank you!
In order to
present my project and to thank the generous donors, I am now giving
conferences on Plato and introducing Plato to everyone through a website: “Platosphere”.
Tomorrow, if I can carry on with my work, Platosphere could be a bilingual reference
website on Plato, helping both scholars and students, and also presenting Plato
to non specialists in layman’s terms. Then you will realise that Plato is accessible,
often witty, and that he even knows how to speak to kids.
Send a stable-lad off to university: you will bring Plato into the marketplace!



Théodore Géricault, The Race of the Riderless Horses, 1817.

Where does your money go?




Cost of the first
  year of PhD studies at Cambridge:
university
  fees (36%), accommodation (27%), and maintenance (37%)
 


25 000 €




Already funded (publishing):


17 000 €




Remaining
  gap :


8 000 €




Risks and challenges
A lot of money needs to be raised. But it's possible! If I can finance my first year of studies, it will be easier to fund the remaining ones:


thanks to
your support, more donors will trust my project, particularly private
companies and foundations.

thanks to
my experience of crowdfunding, next year I'll be able to launch a more successful campaign.

many job
opportunities are offered to Cambridge students, particularly during holidays.



Other ways you can help

There are other ways to help besides monetary donations: spread the word! 

Share this page on Facebook, Twitter and Google+ (see top of page),
Share Platosphere on social networks,
Like my Facebook page.



Thanks, already...
to the Filigrane Choir, to Albert,
Almut, Anne, Elsa, Emmanuelle, Guy, Marie Annick, Maximilien, Moritz, Ragip,
Sandy et Véronique for talking and singing so cheerfully in the pitch. Thanks to Elizabeth, for reviewing this text so generously. Thanks to David for everything, and even more!


 EN FRANÇAIS!

story:
ChildAid (Eid) 4 Gaza was our response to uplift the spirit of the beautiful children of Gaza.  Eid Al-Adha gives us the chance to assist families to address the needs of the children.

We were connected to a group of teachers in Gaza who were very concerned about the emotional and psychological impact of what the children had experienced especially during the last Eid Al-fitr.

A majority of the Palestinian children suffer from PTSD (post traumatic stress disorder) following the months of July and August, having lost homes or loved ones.

(http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn25932-gaz...)

The impoverished families of the traumatized children find providing a therapeutic entertainment environment, unaffordable.

Hence, we felt the need to do a flash crowdfund to ensure the children get an Eid after the one that had been robbed from them. 

The Impact

This Eid project is the start of a long-term plan that would give hope and inspire the children to greater heights through education.

500 homeless children from low-income or limited income families in East Gaza areas namely Al-Shujaeia, Al-Sabra and Al-Zaytoon will be invited to an open house over 3 days.  There, they will be treated with clothes, snacks, toys and gifts, a trip to the park and the pool, the way Eid Al-Adha is supposed to be celebrated in Gaza.  This has been a long forgotten tradition of the children of Gaza.  We hope to bring social and emotional normalcy as quickly as we can to these children.

Let's show the children of Gaza the world cares.  Strength comes from unity.  We are the world and the children are our future.

****************************************************************************

The world has indeed shown we care!  We know we’ve exceeded our target and we’d definitely be moving along to the next step of our work with the children through any excess that we would be collecting over the next few days until the campaign ends.

You guys are great!  And we would definitely keep everyone who has embarked on this with us updated every step of the way!  Stay tuned!

story:
Slow Food promotes good, clean and fair food for all.

As co-chair of my local chapter, I actively believe in the idea that no one should be denied access to a healthy meal for any reason.  Two years ago I began giving cooking demonstrations to the underprivileged of urban Knoxville for a non-profit that is committed to holistic change for the homeless and marginalized- not just a handout. Most of our friends aren't homeless, but they are below the poverty line and faced every month with the question of "do I pay rent or do I buy groceries?" Using produce from an Americorp community garden I prove week after week that you CAN eat healthy on a tight budget.  My demonstrated meals are never more than $1 per serving.  This summer will mark the 3rd season that I have taught canning classes.  Our focus this year is on tomatoes and I am organizing a movie night fundraiser to purchase the jars I will need to not only teach a skill, but also supply food for winter demonstrations.

 

I hope to raise funds to attend Slow Food USA's National Congress in New Orleans this year in order to brainstorm and problem solve with other leaders on ways to better promote food justice in my own community.  I was awarded a scholarship through a grant provided by Kellogg's that covers most of my expenses, but I still need a little boost to get me to my goal.  Please consider giving to me so that I may give to others.

 

Everyone deserves the right to healthy food.  Please help me attend Slow Food USA's National Congress so I can learn better strategies to tackle this problem in my hometown.
