story:
My name is Shane Atkinson and I am the volunteer Muslim Chaplain for Durham Regional Hospital in Durham,NC. 

 

There is an amazing opportunity to attend the 4th Annual  Muslim Mental Health Conference in Michigan on October 5th and 6th.

Here are a few of the topics that will be discussed:

Basics of Mental Health and Basics of Boundaries
Hamada Hamid, Do, MPH and Amal Killawi, LLMSW

Effective Listening
Imam Jones, Chaplain AbdulMalik Negedu and Chaplain Matiniah Yahya

Substance Abuse
Cynthia Arfken, PhD and Hakeem Lumumba, PhD

At-risk Muslim Adolescents & Emerging Adults
Sameera Ahmed, PhD

How to Assess and Prevent Suicide in the Community
Jan Collin-Eaglin

The Imam’s Role in Mental Health Promotion: A Study at 22 Mosques in New York City’s Muslim Community
Wahiba Abu Raas

 

 I dismissed attending as I don't have the funds for travel expenses. Then I realized it is very important for the Muslims in the triangle that I try to attend this conference. I have become a Muslim Chaplain almost by default as I am often the only muslim to respond to a hospitals call for help. I had two of my children pass away so I have first hand experience with the healing power of our tradition.

 

 

I need assistance with airfare and lodging to attend the conference.

Airfare as of today is around $500.

The hotel is $100 per night plus tax so that's $300+ dollars.

Cabfare and dinner would be the remaining expenses.

 

For everyone that donates I will send out a quarterly email update of how what I gained from the conference is being put into practice throughout the following year. I would also like to share what I learn in a discussion group at a Masjid or community center.

 

I have reached out to the local Masjid for assistance but have received no response. Quite often we don't value pastoral care until we need it ourselves. We have a couple of projects being founded by young muslims as 'third spaces' that would benefit from the information taught at this conference as well. 

 

If you can't contribute financially please remember me in your prayers and spread the word about my campaign.
story_txt:
My name is Shane Atkinson and I am the volunteer Muslim Chaplain for Durham Regional Hospital in Durham,NC. 
 
There is an amazing opportunity to attend the 4th Annual  Muslim Mental Health Conference in Michigan on October 5th and 6th.
Here are a few of the topics that will be discussed:
Basics of Mental Health and Basics of BoundariesHamada Hamid, Do, MPH and Amal Killawi, LLMSW
Effective ListeningImam Jones, Chaplain AbdulMalik Negedu and Chaplain Matiniah Yahya
Substance AbuseCynthia Arfken, PhD and Hakeem Lumumba, PhD
At-risk Muslim Adolescents & Emerging AdultsSameera Ahmed, PhD
How to Assess and Prevent Suicide in the CommunityJan Collin-Eaglin
The Imam’s Role in Mental Health Promotion: A Study at 22 Mosques in New York City’s Muslim CommunityWahiba Abu Raas

story:
Free Your Star Foundation is a grass-roots organization (currently applying for 501c3 status) that launched in 2011. Last September we were delighted to award our first scholarship recipient, Shean England, an independent student at LIM College in NYC. We were moved by Shean's story and his dedication to mentor Free Your Star high school interns.

Shean is eager to graduate this May, as an independent student he does not have the financial resources to pay for his last semester. Rather than give up on his dreams he is working to raise money while interning to keep momentum towards his career. Please help Shean finish his degree! Learn more about him below...

 

“Your mother is gone man” are the words that continue to ring through my head even two years after the passing of my mother. In May of last year, at the completion of my junior year, my mother, Lucretia Westbrook, passed away from cancer. Initially starting out as breast cancer, the cancer spreaded to other organs in her body, which made her lose her two-year battle with cancer.

 

Being the middle child, for I have an older sister and a younger brother, and the “man” of the house I had to make an important decision that would heavily impact my future. I had the option to stay in Baltimore and look after my little brother or continue my college education. Because my mother heavily enforced the importance of an education and made it imperative that I obtain my degree, I decided to stay in college. Also, graduating from college would not only be an accomplishment because I am the only male in my family who has gone to college. It would also be my mother’s reward for raising an educated African American male in a single-family household.

 

Maintaining above a 3.0 GPA, I have worked tirelessly to be a role model for my brother and to not let my mother’s hard work be in vain. Not only do I want to continue to be a role model for my brother, but I also want positive effect the life of other young children growing up in an urban environment who lost a parent due to drugs, abuse, cancer, etc. I believe that everyone deserves an equal opportunity to be successful and I want to be that resource that enable these adolescents and teenagers maximize their full potential.

story:
Short Summary

This campaign has been created to help out a good friend of ours. For years, Casey has been building a dream: A place for all his friends and familiy (and even strangers) to get together for good times and to make memories. He has put his heart and soul into building the perfect place, complete with fully functioning vintage pinball machines lining the walls, a lounge with couches, a barbeque, and even a bar. He has always offered this "Mancave" as a place for people to hold their parties, free of charge or obligation.

Unfortunately, hard times have fallen on us all, and now Casey needs us to help keep this dream alive. A few of us have gotten together to help Casey pay the rent and keep this amazing place from becoming only a memory.

Your contributions will allow a dream to live on. A place where anyone is welcome with open arms!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise enough money to cover the rent for next 6 months. This will give Casey enough time to get back on his feet without losing his special place. All of the $5000 requested will go directly to the rent and utilities only.

In exchange for your generosity, you will have the opportunity to select one of the great perks we have listed to the right side of this screen! These perks are Pinball/Mancave based and some of this stuff is not readily available to the public.

Even if our entire goal is not reached, any funds received will go directly to the Mancave's rent and utility bills.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if folks cannot help the project financially, after all, that's why we created this project! But that doesn't mean you can't help us at all. If everyone who visits this page can simply help spread the word by telling a few of your friends to check out this page and our Facebook page, we would greatly appreciate it!

story:
Hello! I am a Paraprofessional Educator (aka a Teacher's Aide) at Vetter Elementary School in Eatontown, NJ. I also run our 6th Grade Art Club, a 1-hour after-school program which runs for 16 weeks.

While I am paid a $37 stipend per session ($592 for the entire program), I do not receive a budget for supplies to give the children. I usually just use my stipend to buy materials.. in essence volunteering my time to teach the class, and cover any additional costs out of pocket. Sadly, I do not make a salary anywhere near that of a teacher, but I do what I can to provide materials for as many projects as I am able.

In recent years, I have had to limit my program to no more than 10 students.. simply because even adding projects using recycled and scrap materials to those made of store-bought supplies, it costs more than I can afford for a larger class. It breaks my heart to tell children who want to participate that they can't join.. knowing that if I had the money, I would not need to turn them away.

This coming school year, we will have more than TWICE the number of 6th grade students than we've had in recent years! Many had come to me in the final weeks of this past school year.. each of them asking for a chance to get into the art club when it begins this September. I hedged around giving them an answer, knowing that there was no possible way I could afford to let them all in.

I recently heard about the indiegogo.com program, and for my students' sakes, decided to give it a try.

My hope is to raise $1,260 to purchase 9 projects worth of materials for approximately 20 children (roughly $7 per project, per child).

This money is strictly for the children! Should more than the goal amount be raised, whatever is not spent for the art club will be donated to our school's PTO fund, which can be used to give wonderful programs and opportunities to all the students Vetter School.

I hope that you will consider making a pledge. Even a single dollar can go a long way to helping a child feel the joy and pride of creating something beautiful! Please share this campaign and help spread the word.

Thank you for helping 'my kids'. :)

story:
(Please excuse my photo. It was  scratched.
Tuesday, June 26th, 2012
 
 
      TEACHER ATTACKED AND INJURED BY STUDENT - IN THE CLASSROOM!
 
Dear Donors,
 
My name is (Ms.) Lorna Beach-Mathura. I am a former certified teacher employed by the Miami-Dade County Public Schools system in Miami, Florida, USA. I AM A VICTIM OF SCHOOL VIOLENCE - THE STUDENT-ON-TEACHER KIND.

I became a teacher to answer the urgent call and need for certified teachers in South Florida. My subject areas were English and Journalism. I wanted to teach students to read and write. It was my contibution to the community and a way to give something back.

I was six months pregnant with my fourth child when I was approached by an Assistant Principal to work in the school that my sons attended. They desperately needed someone to work as a Substitute Locator. This job entails locating substitute teachers to temporarily fill the positions of absent teachers on a daily basis.

Although I was currently enrolled as a Masters Degree candidate at a local private university, I agreed to do the job. I worked from home in the mornings and on the weekends, and I worked at the school in the evenings. It was a challenging and stressful job, but on the whole I was able to cover many of the teacher absences.

When it was apparent that the need for more teachers was indeed great, I decided to become certified and teach full-time.

I was first abused (slapped ferociously) by a 6 yr. old kindergarten student (a boy) who had a violent temper. He slapped me about six times on my arm and leg when I told him to sit quietly and do his assignment. He had been very disruptive and was annoying the other students. I stood there in shock as this little kid slapped me over and over again, and I never fought back.

I was covering for the absent teacher and no one had told me about him beforehand. I later learned that he had "pulled scissors" on other kindergarten teachers, and thrown down desks and chairs in every classroom in which he was placed.  They were all afraid of him. My skin stung for more than six months after that slapping incident. I got a lot of pain from the slapping. He received a 10 day suspension.

This was my first introduction to school violence against teachers (in elementary school), and it was very painful. I would later be cursed out in high school  (see my school identification card), and stepped on, grabbed, yelled at, and pushed and shoved in middle school.

I endured all of the abuses and bullying with the steadfast aim of making a positive difference in the lives of the children of my community. But alas, my good deeds and good intentions would be punished and my teaching career would be cut short.

On March 1st, 2005, while proctoring a State of Florida mandated test, I was viciously and violently attacked by a male middle school student named Zackery Ba-Mungin. He disrupted the test and annoyed the other students by walking in and out of class without permission. On his last re-entry, I met him at the door and asked him to stay there. He began pushing and shoving me until I became wedged between the heavy metal door and the door jamb.

As I struggled to close the door he stuck his foot into the doorway and began to body-slam me. This struggle lasted for 3 to 4 minutes while I asked him to stop hurting me. He did not stop until another teacher appeared in the doorway of another classroom. As I called out for help, Zackery finally stopped.

He was arrested that day and charged with FELONY BATTERY ON A SCHOOL OFFICIAL, while I was sent to the doctor. I sustained a broken neck, broken back, and a contusion to my right shoulder. That was the end of my teaching career, although I did not know it then.

It took Zackery Ba-Mungin two years to plead guilty to battering me. But, he never showed up for sentencing the following month. He has not been punished. There was a bench warrant issued in the case. So, instead of him being punished, I was punished.

My job was terminated while I was on approved leave of absence due to injuries I sustained. I had to pay for most of my medical care and physical therapy treatments. I had to seek out doctors who could help me recover. Yet, I am still not recovered. I had to pay for pain medications. I ingested thousands of pills; endured hundreds of needle injections; made over 200 trips to various doctor appointments, and visited a psychologist and psychiatrist several times for therapy and medications. It was torture.

All of this was paid for out-of-pocket  by me. The School Board refused to authorize the treatments that were needed to help me get better. Its refusal to help me made my conditions worse. I was also treated like the criminal, although I was the victim of a crime ON SCHOOL PROPERTY. Its lawyers investigated me, poked around in my personal affairs, vilified me among other lawyers and my own doctors, and disrespected and denied me at every level.

The School Board's agents refused to give me proper medical care as mandated by the workers' compensation laws of Florida. They also owe me for several years of monetary benefits that I need, especially now. To date, The Board's administration has paid one outside lawyer over $50,000 to avoid paying me the lost wages benefits that I am lawfully owed.

Because of the physical attack, and the resulting injuries, I have been left with severe chronic pain and mental depressionm among other maladies. My disabilities have taken a huge toll on me and my family life, income, career, and every aspect of my life. The pain is the worst, especially during stressful times like now.

I would just like to say that I was a good teacher, and I have outstanding teaching performance evaluations. I have never had any disciplinary problems, and I showed up to work on time and regularly. I treated my students well. I bought them treats and school supplies. I also taught them manners and tips on courtesy and politeness. However, as you read before,  Zackery Ba Mungin did not behave in accordance with my teachings. He missed a lot of time from school, so he may have been absent when the lessons were taught.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Within recent months, I have fallen behind on my mortgage payments. The cost of everything has increased, and I have had to start repaying my $180,000+ in student loans. The monthly payment is $876 for two two loans. These loans were taken out to pay for the advanced degrees I would have needed to become a school administrator.  With the increased income, I would have been able to repay the loans, but I was thwarted in my attempts to better myself, and the lives of students in Miami-Dade County, Florida.

The following are the things I need at this time:

               I need  enough money to place a downpayment of 20% (or $30,000 USD) on a modest, single family house that i wish to purchase. 

               Some of the money will be used to pay the very pressing bills that I have had to ignore due to lack of money.

               Since we have to move to another, less expensive county in Florida, I have to pay relocation or moving expenses - rental truck, movers, gas, etc.  We have to move by the end of July, 2012.

               I will also use  some of the money to help other teachers who have been mistreated in the workplace and have lost their jobs. 

As a totally and permanently disabled former teacher, I can no longer work. The monthly disability income that I currently receive is a quarter of the salary I made before my job was snatched away from me.

PERKS:

$100.00 or more.

          In 1993, I participated in the recording of a compact disc (CD) that falls within the category of "Cool Jazz" or"New Adult Contemporary" music.  I shall award copies to donors of $100.00 or higher - as long as supplies last.

$20.00 to $99.00  

        For the people who do not live in Florida, or those who have never been to any of the attractions that the Sunshine State has to offer, I will award various memorabilia. These range from: caps, t-shirts, key chains, postcards, buttons, or any other licensed items from Disney World, Universal Studios, Sea World,etc. in Orlando.

$1.00 - $19.00

        I will send personal "Thank You" cards via mail to all who have contributed to this worthy campaign.

If the $50,000.00 goal is not reached, I shall still use any money donated to pay bills or for the partial downpayment on a home.

 

The Impact

The generous donations that will be generated will benefit me and others who have tried to make the lives of others better in this world. I have helped many people from all walks of life, and in different capacities. I enjoy using my knowledge to help others who cannot help themselves. When I heard about Karen Klein, the bus monitor, my first thought was to donate to her vacation fund. I did make a donation onlline and was happy to do so.

And, after I did, I realized that I also need help, and perhaps I may also get help from other generous people. I know what it is like to be abused, bullied and physically attacked while doing a job.

The difference between my situation and Karen's is that I was left permanently and totally disabled and I can no longer work. I was also left with chronic bodily pain and depression. So any help will be graciously accepted.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If there is anyone that cannot offer a monetary donation, I would appreciate your help in informing others about my plight. My story of student-on-teacher abuse is real and can be proven. So please spread the word as quickly as possible since my moving date is imminent.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word for me. As a senior citizen, 50+, I am at the end of the working spectrum, so my need is greater than usual.

Thank you so very much for allowing me to share my story of student-on-teacher abuse and subsequent permanent disability.

Sincerely yours,

Ms. Lorna Beach-Mathura

Disabled Teacher and School Crime Victim

        For the people who do not live in Florida, or those who have never been to any of the attractions that the Sunshine State has to offer, I will award various memorabilia. These range from: caps, t-shirts, key chains, postcards, buttons, or any other licensed items from Disney World, Universal Studios, Sea World,etc. in Orlando.
$1.00 - $19.00
        I will send personal "Thank You" cards via mail to all who have contributed to this worthy campaign.
If the $50,000.00 goal is not reached, I shall still use any money donated to pay bills or for the partial downpayment on a home.


 
The Impact
The generous donations that will be generated will benefit me and others who have tried to make the lives of others better in this world. I have helped many people from all walks of life, and in different capacities. I enjoy using my knowledge to help others who cannot help themselves. When I heard about Karen Klein, the bus monitor, my first thought was to donate to her vacation fund. I did make a donation onlline and was happy to do so.
And, after I did, I realized that I also need help, and perhaps I may also get help from other generous people. I know what it is like to be abused, bullied and physically attacked while doing a job.
The difference between my situation and Karen's is that I was left permanently and totally disabled and I can no longer work. I was also left with chronic bodily pain and depression. So any help will be graciously accepted.


 
Other Ways You Can Help
If there is anyone that cannot offer a monetary donation, I would appreciate your help in informing others about my plight. My story of student-on-teacher abuse is real and can be proven. So please spread the word as quickly as possible since my moving date is imminent.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word for me. As a senior citizen, 50+, I am at the end of the working spectrum, so my need is greater than usual.
Thank you so very much for allowing me to share my story of student-on-teacher abuse and subsequent permanent disability.
Sincerely yours,
Ms. Lorna Beach-Mathura
Disabled Teacher and School Crime Victim

story:
The Young family was preparing to go on vacation in June, 2011 when a tragedy struck. Thirty-three-year-old Kara Martinez left her daughter in the family room for just a moment.

"When I came out of the restroom something told me to look for her. When I went to the back porch I found my daughter lying in the pool."

One year old Savannah Young was blue in the face and not responding. The toddler's grandmother, Karen Young, has a nursing background and started CPR immediately.

Karen Young said, "She was breathing when the medics got here and her oxygen level was 98 percent."

When Savannah was taken away, something went wrong.

Kara Martinez  was told, "During helicopter transport to the hospital, Savannah's status began to decline"

Now three-year-old Savannah is disabled. She eats through a feeding tube and needs full time care.

Martinez says her daughter, "Can't sit up by herself... she can't hold her head up... no walking, talking, crawling. The only thing she can do really is hear."

M.artinez is now trying to get help to pay for medical treatments that might restore some of Savannah's brain functions.

Kara says when her father had the pool installed, he asked the contractor to include the best pool fence they had.  On the day of the accident, one of the latches did not close properly.

"You have to be careful. Anything can happen in the split second. We had security gates. We had locks on the doors. We thought we did everything we could to make sure this wouldn't happen and it did," Martinez explains.

Kara says she has one wish that she hopes will come true someday.

"I would love to have a full recovery, but just to have my little girl look at me and say mommy one more time would mean the world to me. This is something you take granted and miss it terribly when it is gone." 

The money raised will help fund

  • The Procedure of Stem Cell recovery
  • The cost of transportation with accommodations
  • Any extra funds will be set aside for future treatments

Why would you want to donate to Savannah's Cause

Savannah was an active young ten month old little girl, who would brighten up your day everytime you would see her. She was always smiling, laughing and full on energy. In a matter of seconds, Savannah's life was changed forever.

Imagine seeing your little girl lifeless in a pool, panic sets in, and you attempt to rescue her. Savannah was brought back to life, but not without serious brain damage. What was once the a vibrant little girl is now a child that can barely move. She is aware of her family and people around her but unable to interact with anyone.

Her physician believes that beginning treatment before her fourth birthday can greatly benefit her progression.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Just pass on our cause to as many people as you can
  • You may know someone that can help us, let them know

story:
My dream of Passion..

 Oscar Wilde said: ''I regard the theatre as the greatest of all art forms, the most immediate way in which a human being can share with another the sense of what is to be a human being''.
   This quote accurately describes how I feel about acting as an art. I view acting as a way to discover myself while connecting with people, share my emotions, and in the process creating unforgettable moments on stage or screen. Through story telling one can make people smile, make them cry, make them feel, and make them dream...My goal in acting is to do as much as I can to become the best actress and person I can be – in harmony with nature and with the people around me.
   I desire to study at the Lee Strasberg Institute because I feel this is the place where I can learn and grow as an actress through the process of developing The Method.  I admire the work of many actors who were trained in this system and produced magnificent creations worth taking an example from. My favorites are Marilyn Monroe, Angelina Jolie, and Johnny Depp - who with their craft all made me feel something.
   I grew up in an artistic, theatrical environment, which created my deep love for art. For me, acting means sharing, creating, listening, taking a risk, being in the moment…  I can’t imagine my life without it. I believe that art helps us to understand our purpose of existence and who we are as human beings.

                                                                                                    With all my respect for Acting,
                                                                                                      Emilia Morell

My story

I'm 21 years old and originally I come from Poland. I graduated Music School with musician diploma playing violin, viola and piano for almost 12 years.  I come from artistic family-my parents are both ballet dancers. I came to United States 2 years ago as an au-pair <live-in nanny> and I've been living in Seattle, WA. Since I remember I had desire to become an actress.  Thats my passion!! I feel like this is what I want to dedicate my life for!

I applied and officialy got accepted to One Year Conservatory program at Lee Strasberg Theatre & Film Institute in Los Angeles.
Entire cost is $16 500. It's more than I have..and as an international student I can't legally work in the United States. I believe anything is possible and decided that nothing will stop me from pursuing my dreams..


How you can help?
You can contribute to my campaign by making a donation in few varities of amounts- it depends on you how much would you like to share.. No matter how much it will be - I want to thank you SO much!! It means a lot for me. I will never stop following my dreams and I hope yours will come true as well!!

stay inspired.
Emi

story:
My Name is Lora. Thank you so much for your interest in my story. As his sister, it is my duty just like it would be yours, to do your very best for your brother if he ever came in need, and he is in really big need of my help, and yours as well.

He was born with a hole in his heart, and by the time he was six months old he had had two major heart surgeries as featured in this news paper article following his doctors tragic death:

 

This "Miracle Child" has been a true blessing to my family. He is the kindest, sweetest, most outgoing boy I have ever met, and has the most generous soul on this Earth. I came to this site, because I trust in people, and believe that because he is so giving to others naturally, that maybe, just maybe, people that have never had the pleasure of meeting him could just be generous to him naturally.

Upon my brothers 2 heart surgeries before he was even a year old, he then had another at 4 years old, and every time they had to operate it was like taking a deep breath, and holding it, not being able to exhale, until he made it out okay.

At the age of 6 he was tested, and was advanced in his education, he was a gifted child.  

Slowly as the work got harder, my mom began to see a change in his grades. They began to fall hard, and upon his 10 year checkup, we realized that he was slightly brain damaged and had a black hole in his brain.

He needs developmental help from a special school. If he is placed in the regular school system, he has no future, as he cannot keep up at that pace yet. The school that we hope to enroll him in will prepare him for regular school, and teach and nuture him back to being at that level again. This "gifted" child has a bright future. We just need help in placing him in the right environment so that he can flourish and progress at his pace. Our family cannot afford this tuition, it is way too high, and that is why I am asking for help from everyone.

I believe, that I will raise this money for my brother, because he deserves a bright future. Please do your best to help me, even if you just give the minimum, we will be truly grateful.

Thank You 

All My love Lora.

story:
Short Summary

This is for our trip to the national HOSA leadership conference!  We both made it for the Kaiser Permanente test, and Macknzie also made it for taking 2nd place in the state medical spelling competition!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1,700 please!  This will go towards our flight, hotel, conference fees and food of course! 

We don't have much to give back, but we will send you a thank you via Facebook, Tumblr, Twitter, etc.

The Impact

We hope that this will help get us a step up in the medical field.  It will hopefully make us stand out on our college applications so that we can get into a great school to further our medical careers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The one and only Austin Ashe is planning his very first trip abroad. And, much like Elizabeth Gilbert (Eat, Pray, Love), he'll be embarking on a journey of self-discovery where he'll explore new foods, achieve inner peace, and fall in love with an exotic man. j/k about the whole inner peace thing. ; )

But seriously, Austin is a great friend and consummate professional, as well as a tireless student advocate and a brilliant philanthropist who's raised thousands of dollars for meaningful charities. So, who better to support than a man who we all know will make an indelible impact on the world?

Austin's journey will begin in early August, and it will take him from London to Berlin, Amsterdam, and Prague, plus maybe a few other stops here and there. It really depends on how much support we can provide and pull together between now and then. 

Here's the challenge: let's raise at least $1,000 in the next 30 days.

Meeting our goal will cover the cost of Austin's airfare and some local travel. Exceeding our goal will ensure that Austin can make the most of his experience by attending concerts, touring museums, enjoying local cuisine, and, yes, even a few adult beverages!

As you can imagine, no part of this fundraising initiative was Austin's idea, although he is well aware and humbled that we're doing this. And, as a thanks for giving, Austin has agreed to participate in a scavenger hunt of sorts - you give and he does something unusual, hilarious, or just plain ridiculous.

So, please give what you can and keep your eyes on the right sidebar to see the kind of impact - real and comical - that you can have on Austin's experience.

And, please know that Austin and we all thank you for your support!

- Friends of Austin

PS: We're also working on a bon voyage party... details to come!

story:
Short Summary

 

“Boy you’re going to college one way or the other. Either you get an academic or athletic scholarship, but you’re going to school and I can’t afford to send you!”

Those were my Dad's words to me as he dropped me of at the Boy's Club.  My name is Andre (Dré) Woolridge and I am a native of Omaha, Nebraska. I learned the fundamentals of basketball at the age of seven at the local Boy's Club of America.

Sadly, today athletics remain the only way for some to go to college, especially with the rising cost of higher education. But I am here to assist them through basketball!

Basketball is my passion! Basketball has allowed me to to follow a path to higher education, offered me the opportunity to see the world, and broadened my horizons.  Basketball's training and discipline helped me build self-esteem and confidence that I use to this day.  It was an escape from gangs and other pitfalls within the inner-city.  Every kid can benefit from the discipline and work ethic I teach no matter their chosen course in life.  Basketball gives me a unique chance to start my own small business and help our youth in the greater Sacramento area.  

As a high school student athlete, I led my team to the Nebraska Class A State Championship title. I was All State and I am still the Class A all time leading scorer. I received a full scholarship to the University Nebraska and transferred to the University of Iowa after my first year. As a Hawkeye I was named first team All-Big Ten and third team All-American by the Associated Press my senior season.

After graduating from Iowa in 1997, I enjoyed an extensive career playing professional basketball overseas.  I have played professionally in Turkey, France, Germany, Venezuela, Israel and Italy.

In 2007, I had the honor of being inducted to the Nebraska High School Sports Hall of Fame and the Nebraska Black Sports Hall of Fame in 2011.

I want to share my basketball expertise and worldy experience with the youth of the greater Sacramento community and hopefully nationwide.

What We Need and What You Get

We need sponsors for those who have the passion for basketball but cannot afford it.  We need shoes and athletic gear for students who do not have the proper equipment to train.  We also need basketballs, cones, and other basketball equipment.  We have already acquired new gym space but it does not have basketball  goals.  Quality basketball goals start at $3000.00 and we need a minimum of four to fill our space. By contributing, you get to have a positive impact on a childs life. Rest assured that through your gift, they will receive basketball skills and life skills which will translate to all aspects of their lives.

The Impact

Our program teaches kids from all backgrounds to develop their basketball skills. It also emphasizes life skills through that basketball training. I plan to use the growth of my business as a starting point to provide underpriviliged kids with scholarships and mentorship opportunities.  They will also build peer relationships and learn the importance of discipline.

Other Ways You Can Help

For those who cannot contribute financially,  we ask you to spread the word.  We ask that you share this with family, friends, and co-workers.  Also share our story on social media outlets!  Thanks for you consideration.

story:
A Big Thank You

Thanks to everyone who contributed to our project in Phase I.  Your contribution is greatly appreciated and has helped us get one step closer to a new Holocaust museum in Danville, Iowa.  Phase II has been launched to raise the needed funds to start the preparation of the land for the building of the museum.

 

Anne Frank's Iowa Connection

 

Oceans Apart was written and illustrated by two teenage girls from Burlington, Iowa, Hallie Darnall and Haley Villont.  A copy of their work is a wonderful perk for our campaign.

The Wagner sisters in the corn fields of Iowa were pen pals with the Frank sisters ...

Just before the Frank family went into hiding, Anne and her older sister Margot were writing letters back and forth between two sisters in Danville, Iowa named Juanita and Betty Ann Wagner. 

The pen pal project started in Juanita's classroom when teacher Birdie Mathews asked if students would be interested in writing to children abroad.  Juanita drew the name of young Anne Frank and immediately wrote to her at an address in Amsterdam.  Juanita's and Anne's older sisters began to write one another as well. 

Anne was an avid postcard collector and sent her new friend in Iowa a postcard from Amsterdam telling about her hobby.  In a letter from Anne to Juanita she tells of looking at a map of Iowa but not finding Danville.  Anne asked Juanita if it was close to the city of Burlington. 

Then the Nazis invaded and the letters stopped.  The Wagner sisters had no idea the Frank sisters were Jewish but knew they were suffering in the war.  Many years later Betty Ann wrote to Margot asking if her family was all right.  It was then Otto Frank who responded letting Betty Ann know his wife and daughters died in a concentration camp.

Today these precious letters from Anne, Margot and Otto, are at the Simon Wiesenthal Center (a museum focused on racism and the history of the Holocaust) in Los Angeles, California.

Back in Danville there is a very humble museum where school children and visitors can come and learn about Birdie Mathew's pen pal project.  Copies of these very important letters are in Danville, Iowa.  It really amazes children to know the young (now very famous) author of a diary found a place in the heart of a little girl from hometown Iowa.

 

 visit us at Danville Station

See the Frank sister's letter here at Traces.org

 What We Need ...

A new educational facility is desperately needed to share this amazing part of history for school children and adults alike.  The local fundraising has begun with a significant amount raised which will allow us to purchase the property adjoining the current museum.  We are in the final stages of this sale so soon we will have room to build.

Our goal is to build a new Holocaust museum with many first class exhibits.  The building project is estimated to cost $450,000.  Therefore we are launching the fundraising on this site hoping to raise the first $250,000 -- or more!

Once the building project is complete, it will serve as a museum, educational center and library.

We have perks!

  • A thank you card from the school children of Danville, Iowa.
  • A copy of the children's book Oceans Apart - signed by both young authors.
  • A Danville Station tee shirt.
  • In memory of - we will honor your loved one on our Facebook pages.
  • A paving brick with your name engraved outside the new educational facility.
  • A Holocaust Education Book Package to donate to a favorite teacher or school district in your community.
  • Bronze, Silver and Gold Levels of Giving (each assuring you a space on the wall of the new museum letting the world know you helped make this happen!)  You can help us by giving any amount today!
  • We all have someone on our birthday, anniversary, Easter, Passover, Mother's Day or Father's Day list who is hard to buy for.  Please consider donating to this educational cause and we will email you a certificate made out to that special someone.  Then they will know what you did in their name.  Just send us a message and we will take care of it immediately.

“How wonderful it is that nobody need wait a single moment before starting to improve the world.” Anne Frank

The Impact - "If you build it, they will come"

Here in Iowa we believe "if you build it, they will come".  Thousands of school children and visitors from around the world will come to Danville to learn about Anne's connection to Iowa.  We know this new museum will make Anne Frank and the war more real to visitors.  In addition, we believe a children's book entitled Oceans Apart will make this period of history more real to readers.  Your contribution will make a world of difference!

People all around the world know Anne Frank.  Still today, decades after the war, her diary is widely read in schools.  This part of history has great value in Holocaust education all around the world.

The Postcard Project

Even if you cannot give financially, you can do something very important and inexpensive to help this project. Since Anne collected postcards, the children of Danville schools  are collecting postcards with a goal of collecting 1.5 million. 

This will be in honor of the 1.5 million children who perished in the Holocaust.  The children hope to collect cards from all around the world.  It's a great project for anyone, including a classroom in your community!  Tell a teacher about this project today!

Note: To make this more affordable for schools, we found a company who sells a quantity of 500 postcards for $20 plus shipping.  It's an amazing value.  Click here to pull up the flyer for this opportunity.

 

Please mail postcards to:

Danville Schools 419 S Main Street Danville, Iowa 52623 

A Children's Book Written by Kids for Kids

Oceans Apart - The Connection between Anne Frank and Her Small Town Pen Pal

The amazing story of Anne Frank's Iowa connection desperately needs to be told in schools around the world.  Two girls from Burlington wrote and illustrated a children's book on the subject entitled Oceans Apart.  This book is now published as part of the A BOOK by ME series.  To learn more about the book series click here.  www.abookbyme.com

An old fire station currently houses a museum called Danville Station which tells the story of the Wagner sisters.  It is extremely small and doesn't even have a restroom.  Despite this fact, many school children visit Danville each year to learn about Anne Frank's connection to the corn fields of Iowa.

Through local fundraising efforts the funds to purchase the adjoining land have been raised.  We are ready to move forward and build a larger educational museum for children around the country to visit.

A BOOK by ME Holocaust Series

Over 70 books have now been written and illustrated by children for children in this series.  The vision started when Deb Bowen met three Jewish survivors in her area named Esther.  Esther Avruch, Esther Katz and Esther Schiff became dear friends and Bowen could not let their stories die with them.  She asked young people to meet them, hear their stories and then write and illustrate a children's book about their lives.  The writing project has grown by word of mouth.  Today there are stories about Jewish survivors, World War II veterans who were eyewitnesses to the concentration camps and Righteous Gentiles (non-Jews who risked their lives to help a Jewish person).

 

"I started to read the materials and stories, and I could not put them down.   It was so powerful to read both the student's interpretation, as well as the direct stories from the survivors themselves.  I have many times researched and studied the Holocaust, but these stories bring the experience to life."

Mary Jean Eisenhower
CEO People to People International
Granddaughter to President Dwight D. Eisenhower     
 
 
 

 

“Each book in the series is a gem! The individual and personal participation and investment of the youthful authors and illustrators is quite outstanding. May you have continued success in your Holy Work.”

Rabbi Jonathan Porath
Jerusalem

                                                                                                                         

 

Please Help Us Get the Word Out ...

Another thing you can do to help us is to use the share tools to put this amazing project on your Facebook and Twitter.  Call a friend or send an email today.  In doing so, you will help us get the word out about this great project! 

Thank you for helping us make this dream a reality!

 

"Everyone has inside of him a piece of good news. The good news is that you don't know how great you can be! How much you can love! What you can accomplish! And what your potential is."--Anne Frank
story_txt:
A Big Thank You
Thanks to everyone who contributed to our project in Phase I.  Your contribution is greatly appreciated and has helped us get one step closer to a new Holocaust museum in Danville, Iowa.  Phase II has been launched to raise the needed funds to start the preparation of the land for the building of the museum.
 
Anne Frank's Iowa Connection
 
Oceans Apart was written and illustrated by two teenage girls from Burlington, Iowa, Hallie Darnall and Haley Villont.  A copy of their work is a wonderful perk for our campaign.
The Wagner sisters in the corn fields of Iowa were pen pals with the Frank sisters ...
Just before the Frank family went into hiding, Anne and her older sister Margot were writing letters back and forth between two sisters in Danville, Iowa named Juanita and Betty Ann Wagner. 
The pen pal project started in Juanita's classroom when teacher Birdie Mathews asked if students would be interested in writing to children abroad.  Juanita drew the name of young Anne Frank and immediately wrote to her at an address in Amsterdam.  Juanita's and Anne's older sisters began to write one another as well. 
Anne was an avid postcard collector and sent her new friend in Iowa a postcard from Amsterdam telling about her hobby.  In a letter from Anne to Juanita she tells of looking at a map of Iowa but not finding Danville.  Anne asked Juanita if it was close to the city of Burlington. 
Then the Nazis invaded and the letters stopped.  The Wagner sisters had no idea the Frank sisters were Jewish but knew they were suffering in the war.  Many years later Betty Ann wrote to Margot asking if her family was all right.  It was then Otto Frank who responded letting Betty Ann know his wife and daughters died in a concentration camp.
Today these precious letters from Anne, Margot and Otto, are at the Simon Wiesenthal Center (a museum focused on racism and the history of the Holocaust) in Los Angeles, California.
Back in Danville there is a very humble museum where school children and visitors can come and learn about Birdie Mathew's pen pal project.  Copies of these very important letters are in Danville, Iowa.  It really amazes children to know the young (now very famous) author of a diary found a place in the heart of a little girl from hometown Iowa.


 

 visit us at Danville Station
See the Frank sister's letter here at Traces.org
 What We Need ...

A new educational facility is desperately needed to share this amazing part of history for school children and adults alike.  The local fundraising has begun with a significant amount raised which will allow us to purchase the property adjoining the current museum.  We are in the final stages of this sale so soon we will have room to build.
Our goal is to build a new Holocaust museum with many first class exhibits.  The building project is estimated to cost $450,000.  Therefore we are launching the fundraising on this site hoping to raise the first $250,000 -- or more!
Once the building project is complete, it will serve as a museum, educational center and library.
We have perks!

A thank you card from the school children of Danville, Iowa.
A copy of the children's book Oceans Apart - signed by both young authors.
A Danville Station tee shirt.
In memory of - we will honor your loved one on our Facebook pages.
A paving brick with your name engraved outside the new educational facility.
A Holocaust Education Book Package to donate to a favorite teacher or school district in your community.




Bronze, Silver and Gold Levels of Giving (each assuring you a space on the wall of the new museum letting the world know you helped make this happen!)  You can help us by giving any amount today!

We all have someone on our birthday, anniversary, Easter, Passover, Mother's Day or Father's Day list who is hard to buy for.  Please consider donating to this educational cause and we will email you a certificate made out to that special someone.  Then they will know what you did in their name.  Just send us a message and we will take care of it immediately.

story:
Hiya Everyone,

Thanks for stopping by, Paul is my name and I am relatively new to this. As an ordinary guy setting off on an adventure in 2006 I found myself teaching English to a group of kids in a local Childrens home in Kathmandu. This small incident has completely changed my outlook on life and I hope together we can ensure this home can continue to provide holistic care for these happy and healthy kids.

Mitrata Nepal was founded in 2000 to provide food, shelter and education to a small number of children. Since opening, the number of children being cared for has increased and it is currently caring for 22 children who live in the home and 9 educational scholarships for lucky families who would otherwise not be able to afford any schooling.

With Christmas approaching in the western world we will be putting some presents under our trees, for this home we need help putting food on their plates. We need your help to meet the daily running costs of this home:

  • 2 USD will feed 1 child for a day.
  • 20 USD will pay a childs school fees for a month.
  • 100 USD will provide holistic care for 1 child for a month.

OR

  • 1000 USD will cover all staff salaries for 4 months

In aid of this event I will be running my first ever marathon, the 42 km course around my home city, Lucerne, Switzerland will be a challenge for even the most prepared athletes, I am aim to do it with only 4 weeks training (due to an unexpected turn of life events) and under 4 hours, if I cannot achieve my goal I will donate the contents of my personal bank account (2000 pounds) to the cause.

I hope you can see how important this organisation is to me and how necesary it is to ensure these kids are continued to be cared for. I hope you are able to spare some time, energy and money for these children.

All donations of 15 pound or more will receive a thank you card and photo from the children at Mitrata Nepal for your christmas tree. These children are to be the future for this country facing hardship, please help us give them the brightest possible outlook.

Many thanks,

Paul Bolla

story:
Bring The Original Mojo's Café

Back To East Utica 



Bigger Than Kong, Cooler Than Austin Powers!

 ...absolutely no place like it on the planet!


"We opened the Original Mojo's in 2005 as a family venture. My life partner, my wife Terry, worked side by side with our son Cameron, myself and our crew, both day and night. Her drive, her personality, and her cooking and baking skills made Mojo's a place that people enjoyed coming to. Our family left Mojo's as Terry became ill. Though the business continued with new owners, many have told us it just wasn't the same. Terry ultimately lost a hard fought battle with breast cancer, and left this world in 2013.


In Loving Memory Of Terry Lynn Alati

1959 to 2013

After a five year battle we lost our

'Peaceful Warrior' on February 11, 2013


Here with Prejean, her 25 year old Blue Front Amazon Parrot


Now, after her passing, I seek, with the help of our extended family, to pour my heart and soul into this venture as a tribute to Terry. It is what she would have wanted.


Are You Missing Your Mojo? 

 Young and Old - EVERYONE IS. 

Remember, We Always Said, 

It's your place...not ours!


Mojo's is something special. It is like a library or a public park. It is like a temple for your mind. It is a place we can all go to relax, think, learn and to share our knowledge with others. 

If everyone reading this donated, our fundraiser would be done in no time. 

Our Indiegogo campaign has just over two weeks left. Now is definitely the time to consider making a donation of $5, $20, $50 or whatever you can to help launch Mojo's. Don't forget, you are being rewarded with perks. This basically means that you are investing in this project and your investment will be paying off within ninety days. It is a sound investment...don't you think? 

Here is our promise to everyone that helps out and gets us close to our goal. 

We will refund every penny, to each and every donor, if we are not able to open

 Mojo's in December 2013 for any reason whatsoever. PERIOD! So let's just get it done. It is truly a win win project for everyone in our community.


  • Do you have a favorite café now? 
I mean really, can we hang out comfortably at the newly remodeled corporate big chain hamburger joints? Or at franchised mediocre donut places? 

We only have a few small independently run local cafés left. Each and every one is so uniquely wonderful! Please help out!


Located in the Parkway Drugs and Family Dollar Plaza.

IT'S MOJO'S.  Lip smackin', palette pleasin', beverages and food, served up to you by as many of the original Mojo's gang that we can muster up. And when we couple this with our signature 'insanely wonderful' customer service, we all can smile and look back on what is a remarkably incredible life journey. IT'S ALL ABOUT OUR COMMUNITY.

THE SPACE IS AVAILABLE, MUCH OF THE EQUIPMENT IS ALL IN PLACE, AND JOE, CAMERON, AND MARIA ARE READY 'TO GIT R' DONE'! 

  • wE  tHinK  wE  nEEd  MoJOs  bAcK,  dOn'T  yOu?

Raise Your Hand If You Want Mojo's Back! 


"WITH YOUR GENEROUS ASSISTANCE, WE CAN MAKE MOJO'S, ONCE AGAIN, ONE OF THE BEST COFFEEHOUSE/CAFE, HANDS DOWN!"


WHAT WAS YOUR MOST FAVORITE THING ABOUT MOJO'S? 


  • Was it the food?
  • Perhaps the unbelievable beverages?
  • Maybe great customer service.
  • How about being able to enjoy friends & family without the mess at home?
  • Or could it have been a favorite employee that brought you in?


It Is All About The Community

  • Children's Reading Hour and Kidz Wall Art
  • Poetry Night
  • Terry Lynn Alati's Philanthropic Stage 4 Fund
  • Comedy Hour
  • Open Mic Night
  • Spiritual Readings (tarot, tea leaves, etc.)
  • And so much more






We Wore 3 Hats @ 3 Locations @ 1 Time






           

Our Greek Salad

Tuna Stuffed Tomato

20 Below Frozen Hot Chocolate



Scrumptious HomemadeTemptations


Whatever your reason(s) for wanting us back, we hope you will support us here and come in frequently to enjoy - MOJO's CAFE...Because it is, YOUR CAFE.

WE HAVE SOME NEW TREATS IN STORE FOR YOU TOO! But we are keeping them top secret and you will just have to wait to find out what they are. 


The Impact On East Utica 

MOJO's can rise again and be your excellent eclectic café with a full range of foods and a drive through window.  As owners (and workers) we are really friendly people who know how to make not only good coffee, but good food, pastries and friends too!  

We are proud to boast, that our free wireless signal was always up and running for you, with a strong signal and 99.9% uptime.

Our espresso is good enough for a snob who has been living in Washington for maybe too long and the atmosphere is great. Be sure to come in on certain nights of the week and be treated to open mic night or even a live band or two.

Signature espresso drinks prepared by our skilled baristas, delicious! 


Amazing Espresso!
 

A Handcrafted Capuccino!


What We Need 

The Mojo's project needs approximately thirty thousand dollars ($27,000.00) to come to fruition. We need your donations now to raise at least $12,000.00 in this 30 day campaign. In addition to our Indiegogo Campaign, we have raised additional outside funding, secured via savings and a private loan.

Right Now We Need Your Support.

This is the approximate breakdown of how funds will be utilized.

  • $2400 to put the existing equipment into working order. 
  • $7200 to purchase new equipment.
  • $1300 for cleanup, repair and additions.
  • $4100 for new chairs and table alterations.
  • $1600 for interior and exterior signage.
  • $4000 for required permits and deposits.
  • $3600 for initial stock of product.
  • $2800 +/- advertising and operating costs.

Be assured, if we don't reach our entire goal, we still plan on forging ahead, but we will have to proceed on a smaller scale. 


We interrupt your regularly scheduled program for a word from Maria


Hey listen, we are not into the video shooting commercial stuff. So you got a few blooper style video flops, ala Maria. Think you can do better? Make your own video. LOL! 


Please Help Us Get The Word Out

SPREAD THE WORD! Please folks, you have to blast this AROUND if we are going to get the word out. So make some noise about Mojo's. Use Facebook, Twitter, Email, Text, Phone Call, or send a carrier pidgeon, for 'crying out load.' Just do whatever it takes! 

Only you can bring back the Magic Mojo!

And speaking of Mojo, and most of all...we need Maria back! In order to get her back full time and keep her exclusively @ Mojo's, she needs for us to supply her with health insurance benefits. By giving Maria a good salary and health insurance, (combined with her exceptional tip earning abilities) we will be giving her a solid foundation to build on for a very happy future. It truly is a win-win situation for all of us, because we will have the best! The one and only MARIA REBISZ!


I personally want to thank everyone for all of your kindness, support and enthusiasm. I am ready to work hard and I hope to see you...at Mojo's. LET'S DO IT.!



Joanne & Maria @ The Drive Thru in 2006


Maria, Joanne, Carlene Xmas 20??



Our Giant Seven Layer Super Duper Cookie Pizza (new for 2013)

OK, here is a sneak peak at one of our new surprises. Terry and I concocted the recipe a couple of years ago. It's the round shape and the diameter of a medium pizza, so you cut it with a pizza cutter! Ooey Gooey to enjoy with friends & family. Take one home or bring it with you to any function or occassion. And don't worry, they will also available in small squares like our homemade brownies.


This Is Our Original Build Out In 2005 At A Cost Of Over $120,000.00.

It was just cement walls until we got in there and worked our magic. Cameron was 10 years old and he had a blast going up and down on the electricians 12' contraption.


Our Sweetheart Terry Creating Some Mojo During The 2005 Build Out


Terry's Favorite Wall Light...In Honor Of Her Passing, Let's Make It Shine Bright 24/7.

What Color Light bulb shall we illuminate?



Our Beloved Terry Hard @ Work, at the Original Mojo's, 

1256 Albany Street, Utica, New York 13501. Circa 2006

That's Bart Tuttle in the background & Halee Serianni @ The Counter. 

Let's Hope Bart & Even Halee Can Both Work Part Time In 2014! 

We Love You & Miss You Terry Lynn Alati.

By giving Maria a good salary and health insurance, (combined with her exceptional tip earning abilities) we will be giving her a solid foundation to build on for a very happy future. It truly is a win-win situation for all of us, because we will have the best! The one and only MARIA REBISZ!


I personally want to thank everyone for all of your kindness, support and enthusiasm. I am ready to work hard and I hope to see you...at Mojo's. LET'S DO IT.!



Joanne & Maria @ The Drive Thru in 2006


Maria, Joanne, Carlene Xmas 20??


Our Giant Seven Layer Super Duper Cookie Pizza (new for 2013)
OK, here is a sneak peak at one of our new surprises. Terry and I concocted the recipe a couple of years ago. It's the round shape and the diameter of a medium pizza, so you cut it with a pizza cutter! Ooey Gooey to enjoy with friends & family. Take one home or bring it with you to any function or occassion. And don't worry, they will also available in small squares like our homemade brownies.



This Is Our Original Build Out In 2005 At A Cost Of Over $120,000.00.
It was just cement walls until we got in there and worked our magic. Cameron was 10 years old and he had a blast going up and down on the electricians 12' contraption.



Our Sweetheart Terry Creating Some Mojo During The 2005 Build Out




Terry's Favorite Wall Light...In Honor Of Her Passing, Let's Make It Shine Bright 24/7.
What Color Light bulb shall we illuminate?


Our Beloved Terry Hard @ Work, at the Original Mojo's, 1256 Albany Street, Utica, New York 13501. Circa 2006

That's Bart Tuttle in the background & Halee Serianni @ The Counter. 
Let's Hope Bart & Even Halee Can Both Work Part Time In 2014! 
We Love You & Miss You Terry Lynn Alati.

story:
Next Up Foundation is a unique non-profit organization that provides FREE after-school skateboarding mentoring programs in underserved areas. Our mission is to help underserved youth of diverse backgrounds overcome their unique challenges in order to become successful and flourish, by supporting their development and education and promoting a healthy lifestyle.

We're ready to expand! In just five years of operation we've served over 12,000 kids. Our goal is to serve 6,000 kids in 2016 alone, BUT we need your help! We are raising funds to sustain and expand our programs in order to mentor more youth and more greatly impact the community.


About Us

  • Next Up Foundation's founder, Vinicius "Vina" Tinoco, moved from his home in Brazil to California, armed with a vision of using skateboarding as a gateway to help young people solve their problems and create better lives. Next Up's board of directors and board members include individuals who are passionate about serving community and assisting youth, including Andre Genovesi, Josh Friedberg, Neal Hendrix, Matt Piercey, Richard Faris, Dana-Beth Faris, Joseph Madrid, Mike Arrache, Lisa Timmons, Kevin Webber and Austin Black.
  • We teach our kids life-lessons inherent to successful development through our CHANGE MENTORING PROGRAM (Community, Health, Action, Nurture, Goals, and Experience).
  • We currently work in Anaheim and Long Beach. In Anaheim we work with the City of Anaheim, and in Long Beach we collaborate with the Boys & Girls Club. We also have worked with the Boys & Girls Clubs of Santa Ana and Anaheim, providing this service mainly on volunteer hours.
  • We've done over 400 sessions of our programs, put in nearly 5,000 hours of volunteer work, and served over 12,000 kids in the cities of Anaheim, Santa Ana, and Long Beach.


What We Need & What You Get

Overall, we hope to raise $10,000 to operate for 12 months. Here's how your contributions will help:
  • OUR KIDS: Purchasing safety equipment and skateboards, providing uniforms (shirts and hats and in some instances shoes), paying for educational field trips to companies and skate parks, printing our leadership CHANGE notebooks, and purchasing a comprehensive liability insurance.
  • OUR FOUNDATION: All funding we receive establishes financial history and helps to build budget management experience, consequently making application for grants easier. Our future goals include turning our passionate team of volunteers into sustainable and expandable business, hiring a full-time program coordinator, and training new mentors.

Why needed now? 

  • We are planning to rebuild our program in Santa Ana, extend our program in Anaheim to mentoring twice a week, maintain our program in Long Beach, and start an entirely new program in Los Angeles. We have been approached about expanding our programs to Jupiter, FL; Fallbrook, CA; Los Angeles, CA; Federal District, Mexico; Brownsville,TX; Spokane, WA; Fort Collins, CO; San Fernando Valley, CA; Stanton, CA; San Bernardino, CA; and many more. The sky is the limit!  We want to bring Next Up Foundation to as many cities as possible, where deserving youth can access adult mentors who will inspire them to persevere and overcome adversity, recognize and stay away from bad influences, study and stay in school, and take care of their bodies.
  • We have run these programs solely through volunteer work, donations, and through the sacrifice of Vina, our founder. Without your support, we will not be able to grow and help more kids who need mentorship.   
Next Up Foundation has the approval and support of many important figures in our community who have seen the difference Next Up makes in the lives of kids who participate. Many have helped provide perks for our donors, among them some experiences that might happen just once in a life-time. Check them out!!


The Impact

“An after school program is an extremely powerful anti-crime weapon.” -Chief William Bratton, Los Angeles Police Department

  • 12- to 17-year old kids left unsupervised three or more days per week are twice as likely  as other kids to hang out with gang members, three times as likely  to be engaged in criminal behavior, and three times as likely  to smoke marijuana. (Opinion Research Corporation, 2006.  FIGHT CRIME: INVEST IN KIDS California, California Survey of Teens.)
  • In 2014, nearly 1,200,000 of California’s children would participate in an after school program if one were available. (After School Alliance)

  • The predominant challenges parents face enrolling their child in an after school program include: preference for alternative activities and overly expensive after school programs (average of $126 weekly). (After School Alliance)


Other Ways You Can Help

There are countless ways you can help us achieve our goals:

  • Share this campaign through your local network.
  • Introduce us to people you feel could help Next Up Foundation, such as district officials, local news outlets, and school board members.
  • Sign up to volunteer through our website:  www.nextupfoundation.org
  • Donate used goods to Next Up Foundation.

Thank you so much for all of your support!


The Perks


SECRET PRIVATE SESSION WITH PAUL RODRIGUEZ!
Who hasn’t heard of the name P. Rod these days?  Paul Rodriguez is arguably skateboarding’s biggest current celebrity, and there’s no question he lives up to the hype.  Sponsored by Nike, Primitive Skateboarding, and Mountain Dew (to name a few), Rodriguez has achieved three X Games gold medals, multiple Street League wins, and signature Nike shoes. Here's your chance to pick two of your best friends, and have a secret private session with P.Rod. Photographer and filmer will be provided, so you can have personal photos and video of your experience to to keep the memories alive forever.


SKATE AN AFTERNOON WITH CHRIS COLE AT HIS PRIVATE PARK!
Chris Cole has forever impacted the history of skateboarding and remains an extremely relevant name in the sport.  He is a consistent leader in skateboarding competitions, including Street League Super Crown Championship, X Games, Battle at the Berrics, Dew Tour, and many more!  Most notable of Cole’s accomplishments is being twice named Thrasher Magazine’s “Skater of the Year.”  (Only one other skater – Danny Way – can claim the same honor.)  Undoubtedly one of the most talented skaters in existence, Cole actively promotes positivity within skateboarding. Photographer and filmer will be provided, so you can have personal photos and video of your experience to keep the memories alive forever.


PRIVATE SESSION AT THE BERRICS with FELIPE GUSTAVO + 5 FRIENDS!

Felipe Gustavo’s talent and determination within skateboarding is admirable beyond words.  From Brasilia, Brazil, Gustavo quickly established credibility in the industry stateside, becoming back-to-back Run and Gun champion, earning a spot on the renowned Plan B skate team, and gaining sponsorship by LRG, DC, and Venture, among others.  You have the opportunity to skate with Felipe at the most exclusive skate park in the nation: the Berrics.  Owned by skateboarding icons Steve Berra and Erik Koston and home of the world-famous Game of Skate competition, Battle at the Berrics (BATB), the Berrics is a consistent trendsetter and respected force in the world of skateboarding.


PRIVATE SESSION WITH CHRISTIAN HOSOI!

Christian Hosoi is a living legend.  Famous for style, charisma, and insane vertical air, few have skated as hard, fast, or high as this man.  Hosoi came out of one of the original meccas of skateboarding, Venice, California, transforming the sport forever with his fearless ability. (IMPORTANT UPDATE -- PERK VALID FOR ONE PERSON ONLY!)


PRIVATE MINI RAMP SESSION WITH KENNY ANDERSON + $300 GIFT CERTIFICATE FOR THE CRAILTAP WAREHOUSE!

Kenny Anderson has almost 30 years on the skateboard and has no plans to quit.  A Converse and Chocolate professional rider, Anderson’s accomplishments include three pro-model shoes and parts in renowned skate films.  Many regard Anderson as having a cool, smooth style, and he’s just about as genuine a dude as one can ask for.


BACKYARD SESSION WITH ELLIOT SLOAN!
Elliot Sloan is a powerhouse Vert skater from New York City, famous for big moves on the mega ramp. Aside from a successful skateboarding career, including world championships and X Games gold medals, Sloan is a talented guitarist and musician. Some lucky donor will get the chance to hang with Sloan in his own backyard, complete with a vert ramp and pool, jamming, skating, and having one heck of a time!


TransWorld SKATEboarding SESSION!

TransWorld SKATEboarding Magazine was established in 1983 amidst the tumultuous rise of the skateboarding industry.Today, TWS remains one of the most predominant media sources in the industry.  You have the opportunity to bring a skate crew of five to their private training facility in Carlsbad for an afternoon complete with prizes, special appearances, and personal photos and video to keep the memories alive forever.


An 8.5x11 PRINT OF OUR STUDENTS


GREEN DIAMOND HAT 

LRG HAT

RED & YELLOW DIAMOND HATBLACK NEXT UP TEE FRONT & BACK LOGOS

BLACK NEXT UP TEE WHITE & RED FRONT LOGO

WHITE "BE A BUDDY NOT A BULLY" NEXT UP x Don't Care TEE


WHITE LONG SLEEVE YOUTH NEXT UP TEE 


NEXT UP HATS


NEXT UP HOODY

COMPLETE POWELL SKATEBOARD

BRONZE COMBO

3 Hurley boardshorts (32 waist), 1 Hurley sweatshirt, 2 Hurley hoodies, 3 hats (LRG, Diamond, DC), 3 Stance socks, 2 Hurley shirts (large) and 1 Hurley button up shirt.

SILVER COMBO
1 Hurley camo sweatshirt, 3 Hurley boardshorts (32 waist), 2 Hurley boardshorts (youth size), 4 hats (2 Diamond, 1 LRG, 1 DC), 1 Hurley sweatpants (medium), 1 Hurley shirt (large) and 9 Stance socks. 
GOLD COMBO
3 Hurley board shorts (32 waist), 1 Hurley sweatshirt (medium), 2 Hurley hoodies (medium), 4 hats (2 Diamond, 1 LRG, 1 DC), 9 pairs of Stance socks, 2 Hurley shirts (large), 1 Hurley button up shirt and 1 Hurley slim pair of pants.


If you purchase a Next Up T-shirt or sweatshirt perk or a hat perk, please indicate your choice of size and style.  (All hats are snapbacks!)

If you have any questions about Next Up Foundation or our campaign, please don't hesitate to reach out!  We are happy to correspond!

https://www.facebook.com/NextUpFoundation/

Email: NUF@NextUpFoundation.com

From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for supporting NEXT UP!!!

story:
Syrian Refugees

More than 4 million Syrians have fled their country because of war. Most of them come to Turkey. As of April 2015, Turkey has become the world's biggest refugee hosting country with 2.1 million Syrian refugees and had spent more than US$6 billion on direct assistance to refugees. Around 30 percent of them live in 22 government-run camps near the Syrian-Turkish border. Yet, the rest struggle to settle a life for their families in big cities. 

Refugees Istanbul

While Europe struggles over 224,000 refugees, the number of displaced Syrians has reached 330,000 in Istanbul. They come here with a hope to find a work and a home. Everyday you can see more than one Syrian family begging for food at every corner, on every street . In Istanbul alone, 3,000 of them live by begging. 

How They Live?

Most of the families live in abandoned buildings in suburbs of Istanbul. Let aside heating, some houses don't even have doors or windows! Harsh winter conditions make it harder to survive especially for kids. You can see their conditions in the video as well. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UwWzExfyDDo

Every Little Helps

What we would like to do is simply, to buy at least 200 blankets and donate them to the Syrian families in Istanbul before the winter comes. At the end of the campaing we will go to suburbs of Istanbul where they mostly live and try to help as many families as possible. We will share the photos and moments with all of you guys. Most importantly, everyone is welcome to join us.


Who Are We?

We are nine close friends living in Istanbul.  We (Me, Berk, Onur, Safak, Ibrahim, Oya, Dylan, Gocmen) would like to dedicate this campaign to our friend Eda K. who is the prime mover of this initiation. The idea was born when she suggested to do sth good for those in need instead of buying birthday gifts to each other each year. So that's why instead of buying her a gift, we decided to launch this campaign and donate the money we spared for her birthday gift and make it bigger by sharing. This is kind of a surprise for her :) She will see this as soon as the first donation is made.

Thank you Eda for such a meaningful initiation and Happy Birthday again.

Sources for Data

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War

http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/09/15/syrias-new-capital-istanbul

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UwWzExfyDDo

story:
THEY NEED YOU

Most of us are not aware that 17000 children die daily of causes that can be prevented

But we don´t know how easy is to avoid most of these deaths with only a vaccine, a syrup, or access to drinking water.

From San Saturio School we want to help UNICEF to continue saving lives and that´s why we created this campaign.

We think that helping is not something that we have to let others do. Each of us can help in one way or another, and this is the way we´re trying to help children.

Please join my challenge and donate what you can. They need you.

 Contact us:

Twitter: https://twitter.com/theyneedyou_

Instagram: http://instagram.com/they_need_you_/

UNICEF donation page: https://meayudas.unicef.es/colegiosansaturio/th...

e-mail:theyneedyoucampaign@gmail.com

story:
It has always been my dream to touch peoples hearts through music, through my voice. When I was ten years old I stepped onto the stage at the First Presbyterian Church in New Glasgow at the Music Festival for the first time. That was the beginning of ten years of being part of the New Glasgow Music Festival. I will be forever grateful for the educational experiences I have had through this festival. That first day when I was ten years old was when I realized the adjudicator, Monette Gould was the first step towards my dream of being a performer. Now ten years later I can say that I achieved the goal of studying with Monette.

I was very surprised with eyes full of tears when I found out that I would be going to Provincials and now that I have found out I have the chance to go to the National Music Festival I am overwhelmed with emotion. This is everything I could have hoped for at only the age of twenty. Getting to Edmonton is my next goal.

Along with going to Nationals there comes the reality of Travel costs. Team Nova Scotia is completely relying on donations to get us to Edmonton, Alberta. This means that I need to look to my community for people that believe that this is an experience of a lifetime. It gives me a sense of pride to know that I will be representing my hometown and province when I step on stage at Nationals.

You can help by donating on this site (100% of the donations go to my travel funds) or spreading the word via email, Facebook, or any other social media.

Travel Costs $1275-$1475

Flight:

$700.00-$900.00

Ground Travel:

Airport Shuttle Round Trip $30

Accommodations:

Hotel where competitors stay $56.50/night+ tax (5%) =$315.00

Meals:

Breakfast:

Buffet Breakfast (at hotel) $10.00 x 5 days (Wed.-Sun.) Total $50.00

Lunch & Dinner:

A list of restaurants in the area will be provided.

For all meals we have budgeted for about $45.00/day.

Total $225.00

Visit the Website to find out more information about the National Music Festival!

http://www.fcmf.org/

Now ten years later I can say that I achieved the goal of studying with Monette.I was very surprised with eyes full of tears when I found out that I would be going to Provincials and now that I have found out I have the chance to go to the National Music Festival I am overwhelmed with emotion. This is everything I could have hoped for  at only the age of twenty. Getting to Edmonton is my next goal.Along with going to Nationals there comes the reality of Travel costs. Team Nova Scotia is completely relying on donations to get us to Edmonton, Alberta. This means that I need to look to my community for people that believe that this is an experience of a lifetime. It gives me a sense of pride to know that I will be representing my hometown and province when I step on stage at Nationals. You can help by donating on this site (100% of the donations go to my travel funds) or spreading the word via email, Facebook, or any other social media.Travel Costs $1275-$1475Flight:$700.00-$900.00Ground Travel:Airport Shuttle Round Trip $30Accommodations:Hotel where competitors stay $56.50/night+ tax (5%) =$315.00Meals:Breakfast:Buffet Breakfast (at hotel) $10.00 x 5 days (Wed.-Sun.)   Total  $50.00Lunch & Dinner:A list of restaurants in the area will be provided.For all meals we have budgeted for about $45.00/day.                         Total $225.00Visit the Website to find out more information about the National Music Festival!http://www.fcmf.org/

story:
Support the Thunder Pandas & Lunging Lizards!

Include Autism is a 501c3 nonprofit organization that provides therapy and educational services that empower and include individuals with autism in our communities. (Watch our video here.). This campaign raises funds for Include Autism's Baseball League, which provides the opportunity for kids and teens with autism to play on a real baseball team alongside peers with and without autism. 

The Include Autism Basbeball League provides opportunites for youth with autism to:

·  Engage with peers with and without autism

·  Improve health and physical fitness

·  Develop teamwork, leadership, friendship, safety, and behavior management skills

·  Have fun & experience a fundamental part of being a kid

What We Need & What You Get

Many children and teens with autism are unable to participate in extracurricular activities and sports due to the challenges that autism presents. We want you to help make this meaningful part of growing up possible for kids with autism in San Diego. 
  • It costs $4,000 to operate the Include Autism Baseball League each year
  • Although participants pay a nominal registration and uniform fee, we are counting on donations from the community to raise the remaining $3,100 needed to operate the league. 
  • Our goal of $500 will pay for half of the baseball equipment we need
  • Help us raise more than our goal so we can buy the rest of the baseball equipment, pay for field rental, and coaches. 
  • Your donation will be doubled! All donations will be matched by The Law Offices of Howard Kitay up to $5,000!
  • Plus, you'll get really cool perks as a show of our thanks. 

Other Ways to Support the Team

    • Share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, and via email asking people you know to support this cause!
    • Tell people about Include Autism. 
    • Ask people who notoriously give you "that gift you don't want" to donate to this campaign on your behalf instead. 
    • Ask your employer to sponsor the Include Autism Baseball League or match your gift. 
    • Most importantly, be a friend to individuals with autism who you meet in your community!
If you have any questions please contact us at Development@IncludeAutism.org or (858)381-0374. Thank you so much for your support!
