story:
Chicago Ideas is a movement built on one core belief:  When a broad spectrum of thinkers and instigators share ideas, we have the power to transform our world. For one week each October, we bring in over 200 global leaders to share, connect and speak on the world’s most pressing, groundbreaking, thought-provoking issues. Our events foster collaboration, inspire innovation and bring together individuals—including CIW YOU(th)—from across our city, the Midwest and the world.

As a part of our mission to spark connections, CIW YOU(th) provides approximately 500 Chicago Public School students in grades 9 through 12 the opportunity to connect with CIW speakers, city leaders, their peers and the broader community. Created by Chicago Ideas, CIW YOU(th) get unique, behinds-the-scenes access to Chicago institutions; they've explored the business offices of the Bulls, gone onto the tarmac at O'Hare and had small group meetings with speakers like Essence Co-Founder Ed Lewis and former child soldier Ishmael Beah. Access to Chicago Ideas programming empowers students to seek new opportunities, pursue their passions and walk away with a newly inspired outlook on their own potential.  

What We Need

In short, we need books! Many Chicago Ideas speakers inspire our students to learn more. With funding, we'll be able to provide all 500 YOU(th) participants this year with books written  by Chicago Ideas speakers. Past speakers have included:

  • Ishmael Beah, A Long Way Gone
  • Rep. John Lewis, March
  • Mick Ebeling, Not Impossible
  • Chris Gardner, The Pursuit of Happyness

What You Get

Donate enough money to purchase 10 or more books, and you’ll get Chicago Ideas swag, exclusive access to programming and more.

The Impact

By helping us purchase our speakers’ books, you are putting the power of words into the hands of the students who need them most. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with others! Together, we can provide great books to our future leaders of Chicago

story:
Texas Clown Association 2015

This year the TCA Convention will have world class instructors and great shows. but a big change this year is we are bringing joy to kids fighting cancer:

  • Kids will be the focus. This year the big show will host children fighting cancer together with their families. The convention is not just for clowns, it is for the kids.
  • Every penny raised here will go to providing joy to the kids.
  • The All-Star Show is expanded to make it a once-in-a-lifetime event in a real circus tent.
  • The Rosy Nose Clown Alley in Tyler, Texas is a new clown alley and we volunteered to host this year’s convention.
  • Each teacher could be a headliner at any other convention. We are bringing the best teachers to this convention
  • Because this is an ambitious and expensive convention, we need your help. It will be the best you have ever seen having an impact far beyond the members of the Texas Clown Association.

We know that you, our colleges and friends, are caring and generous. We need your help to fund this event and trust we can accomplish great things together.

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the details:

  • The convention will cost over $20,000 total. Less than half of that is covered by registration fees.
  • The added expense this year is from two area.
    • We are bringing in teachers and performers who are the best in their fields. We did not just ask, “Who can we get?” Instead, we asked who would be the BEST in each area.
    • With this much talent, we decided to share the talent with kids fighting cancer. We will have an All-Star show in a circus tent. We will make a once-in-a-lifetime memory for families who deserve to smile and forget their struggles for a little while.
  • We have some fun and interesting perks for contributors. There will be special things to see and do at the convention. There are fun perks even if you cannot attend the TCA Convention or show. We want to make sure that you know how thankful we are for your loving support!
  • Every penny of this campaign will go directly to providing the entertainment for the kids. The clown training and the rest of the convention will be funded through other means. Everything we raise here will go directly to bringing joy to kids with cancer.

The Impact

The impact of your giving will be felt in the community, in the Texas Clown Association, and most importantly by the kids:

  • If you are a TCA member, you will be helping to make this the most memorable convention ever.
  • If you are a member of the Tyler community, you will be impacting kids right here in our community.
  • The Texas Clown Association has a rich history of giving and caring. This organization makes a difference in Texas.
  • The Rosy Nose Clown Alley is a 501c3 Non-profit organization. An accounting firm is overseeing all of our fundraising activities. All of the money raised here goes to help the kids. Not a penny will go to overhead.

Risks & Challenges

Being less than three years old, the Rosy Nose Clown Alley took a couple of big risks.

  • First we took the risk of hosting the TCA convention. 
  • Second we took the risk of expanding the scope of the convention to help children.

All the money raised in this campaign will go directly to providing for the kids. The convention itself will be funded by registration fees and other fund-raising by members of the Rosy Nose Clown Alley.

But we had to commit early to set the things in motion to provide entertainment for the children.

  • We are working with Trinity Mother Frances Hospital, Lil’ Wranglers (a part of the Cattle Barons Gala organization), and the American Cancer Society to identify kids and families who will benefit the most from this event.
  • We had to contact the families and organizations early to set things in motion.
  • Deposits and rental fees that are coming due for facilities and equipment are being paid out of pocket by alley members.
  • We are trusting YOU, our community, to make this happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter what your level of giving is we need additional help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Facebook stories, blog posts, newsletter articles, mentions at meetings, can all help us.
  • This website has tools to help you spread the word!

Together we will impact kids and bring joy...why not?




Perks


$5—Become Famous

For everyone who donates $5 or more we are going to make sure that your name is listed in all the official "Thank You" and contributors lists at the convention. You will get a "Shout Out" on the official Rosy Nose Clown Alley FaceBook page. We are going to say thank you in every way we can and make you famous. Let everyone see that you are a part of the fun and support such a great cause.



$25—VIP Tickets 

During the convention we are having an All-Star show with some of the most entertaining performers, side-splitting gags, and fun interaction. Be right up front for all the action.

This is the amazing show that we are presenting for the brave kids and families fighting cancer. You get to enjoy the show.

  • Best seats in the house
  • Free popcorn
  • Photo opps with the performers

You get it all at this level of giving.



$50—Official Convention DVD

For the first time ever every class, contest, and show will be recorded on video. You will get a DVD of all the best from the convention. The learning, fun, and memories will go on and on.


$100—Sponsor a Family

We are teaming up with Trinity Mother Francis Hospitals, Lil' Wranglers (a part of the Cattle Barons Gala, and the American Cancer Society to bring in children who are fighting cancer, along with their families.

Imagine the joy you will feel when you see the smiles on their young faces as they experience a once-in-a-lifetime show from some of the best performers in the world.



$200—VIP Dinner

This exclusive dinner will allow you to get up close and personal with all the instructors.

You will share a meal, friendship, laughs, and memories will the instructors and performers.

This will be a small gathering at a very nice resturant off-site.

Transportation, food, and tips are all included.

This perk is very special.



$1000—VIP Dinner

This exclusive level of sponsorship is limited to only five sponsors.

This is a perfect way for your whole clown alley or a company to support this wonderful cause.

This level of sponsorship includes some wonderful advantages.

  • A vinyl banner with your group's name will be prominently displayed during the whole convention.
  • A classroom will be named after your group. 
  • Your group will be publicly acknowledged at the All-Star Show.
  • Recognition in printed material at the convention.

story:
Global Health Debates is a prestigious debate event being organized in Manila, the Philippines from 23rd to 27th August, 2015. We are the sole team from Nepal and we are extremely excited to be a part of this amazing learning opportunity, 

However, despite having great interest and preparation, we are not able to entirely fund ourselves due to the financial difficulties. Our organization Debate Network Nepal could not raise funds because our fundraising program was highly affected by the massive earthquake that occurred last April. 

The participation is very crucial as that would help raise the standard of debating in Nepal which is struggling to have a better debate culture.

We are a team of three - two debaters (Raj Kharel and Prizma Ghimire) and an adjudicator (Pradeep Ghimire). We represent Kathmandu University and upon coming back, we are looking forward to expand the debating culture in this university in an intense manner. 

Take us there now please.

story:
As host of Til Debt Do Us Part, Princess and Money Moron I know that people need help figuring money out. And I'm determined to drag the financially illiterate into the 21st century. It's time for everyone to have  the knowledge/skills/attitude they need to make money make sense. 

  • I'm trying to raise money to build an advertising and promotion campaign for My Money My Choices to raise awareness and build new tribes.
  • I can't be everywhere and I can't teach everyone. We need to do this together.
  • YOU can help. You can spread the word. You can share what you've learned. And you can drop a penny or two in the pot to create the campaign.
  • All money raised will go to the My Money My Choices Foundation. This foundation is registered with CCRA (which was no small feat I'll tell ya).
  • Please, please, help me to get the word out. I need YOU to spread the word.  
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Learning about the fish that swim through the city waters is super cool! But dipping your toes in a lake with the backdrop of chirping birds and stillness, can create a sense of wholeness that the wilderness brings. 
Discover Outdoors has adopted a school for a multi-day canoe, camp and hike trek. All but one of the costs have been covered through grants and fund-raising. Help us provide two awesome programs: a naturalist who will introduce these inner city students to real animals in an exciting, unforgettable way! And a star-gazing presentation taught as the students lay outside under the night sky with a million stars overhead.

What We Need & What You Get

  • 100% of these funds will go to pay for these two programs - Stargazing and Wildlife.
  • The total cost is $500.00. $375.00 covers the cost of the wildlife program. $75.00 covers the cost of the stargazing program. And $50.00 will cover the cost of smores!
  • In addition to covering the modest stipend for the naturalist, funds will also be contributed to support and care for the animals and rescue mission. All these critters are rescued, having been abandoned or illegally held.

The Impact

Over the past six months Discover Outdoors Foundation has served almost 500 students and their schools - providing free programs for deserving urban public school students. We take students hiking, fishing, orienteering all over, including the New York City harbor, Hudson River, Harriman State Park and the Delaware River. These are students that likely haven't been to the ocean or to any wilderness area. Most haven't ventured outside their neighborhoods, past the corner bodegas. And we are changing that!

With every student we engage in outdoor experiences, we start a cascade of changes. They begin to think sustainably, see themselves gaining greater opportunities and advancing their education. And this country gains the increased likelihood that the next generation will be prepared to lead to a wilder, healthier world for us all.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please make a donation in any amount if you can. If you aren't able to you can still help:
  • Connect with us on Facebook and Linkedin. Sign up for our newsletter by visiting our website.
  • Get the word out. Make some noise about our campaign
  • Share this Indiegogo campaign.

story:
High Country

The mountains of Colorado are home to hundreds of shepherds, who come from Latin America on contracts and lead solitary lives in tents or trailers as they tend to sheep. Steve and Mary Kreis, who serve on mission with InFaith, recognized an opportunity to ease the shepherds' loneliness and introduce them to the love of Jesus. Steve began to visit shepherds regularly, offering them friendship and opportunities to study the Bible and learn more of God's love for them. Steve and Mary also bring the shepherds tangible gifts, such as books, Bibles, and phone cards to call their families in Latin America.

In August 2013, a film crew from InFaith Pictures traveled with Steve to visit some of the shepherds. The resulting documentary, High Country, gives a glimpse of these shepherds' lives and tells the story of how Jesus is at work in their lives. In conjunction with the November 2013 release of the film, InFaith Pictures is giving viewers the opportunity to become directly involved in the ministry of Steve and Mary Kreis through this indiegogo campaign.

Steve's truck is vital to his ministry; he travels many miles over treacherous roads to meet the shepherds in the remote locations where they work. Over the years, his truck has taken a beating. To continue in service, it needs new tires and a suspension upgrade. We want to raise funds to repair Steve's truck so that it can travel the high country for many years to come. Steve is one of the few people who take the time and effort to visit these men where they camp; if he were unable to get to them, he would be missed.

InFaith Pictures, InFaith's nonprofit film production company, uses documentary films to tell the story of Jesus. It is the first fruit of InFaith's new campaign to draw Christ-followers with creative skills into vocational Christian service through a ministry residency that helps people with dreams turn their seed ideas into fruitful ministry. InFaith has been finding new ways to introduce people in the United States to Jesus since 1790; InFaith Pictures is the most recent outgrowth of InFaith's mission to tell the story of Jesus in a way that contemporary listeners can understand.

 

What We Need

Steve and Mary Kreis have received a quote for $800 for a suspension upgrade and $815 for new tires. We would like to raise enough money to pay for these repairs and related expenses, which include fundraising costs and funds for administrative services that InFaith provides for everyone who serves with them.

The Kreises raise funds for living and ministry expenses through InFaith, which is a 501(c)(3) organization, so your donation to this campaign is tax deductible. Any funds raised above the goal will go toward Steve and Mary's general ministry expenses, which includes fuel and ongoing vehicle maintenance.

 

 

What You Get

As a thank you for your contribution, you will receive the following:

For a $10 contribution:
You will receive a copy of the Spanish-language newspaper Steve and Mary produce for the shepherds they visit. El Periódico del Pastor ("The Shepherd's Newspaper") includes exchange rates, news from a shepherd's home country, and photos of the men Steve visits.

For a $30 contribution:
You will receive an MP3 recording of the film's soundtrack, composed by Benjamin Crandall.

For a $60 contribution:
You will receive a 12"x"18" limited-edition High Country poster. (Visit the High Country page on InFaith Pictures' website to see the poster.)

For a $100 contribution:
Your name will be printed in El Periódico del Pastor, a copy of which you will receive. You will also receive the MP3 soundtrack and a High Country poster.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

High Country is the first documentary film produced by InFaith Pictures. As a new production company, we need your help in getting the word out. Please share our videos with your friends and family through social media, and please keep us in prayer as we film more stories about Jesus in today's world.

Even after this campaign ends, Steve and Mary Kreis will need continuing prayer and financial support. You can donate to their ministry at any time through InFaith's website.
story_txt:
High Country
The mountains of Colorado are home to hundreds of shepherds, who come from Latin America on contracts and lead solitary lives in tents or trailers as they tend to sheep. Steve and Mary Kreis, who serve on mission with InFaith, recognized an opportunity to ease the shepherds' loneliness and introduce them to the love of Jesus. Steve began to visit shepherds regularly, offering them friendship and opportunities to study the Bible and learn more of God's love for them. Steve and Mary also bring the shepherds tangible gifts, such as books, Bibles, and phone cards to call their families in Latin America.
In August 2013, a film crew from InFaith Pictures traveled with Steve to visit some of the shepherds. The resulting documentary, High Country, gives a glimpse of these shepherds' lives and tells the story of how Jesus is at work in their lives. In conjunction with the November 2013 release of the film, InFaith Pictures is giving viewers the opportunity to become directly involved in the ministry of Steve and Mary Kreis through this indiegogo campaign. 
Steve's truck is vital to his ministry; he travels many miles over treacherous roads to meet the shepherds in the remote locations where they work. Over the years, his truck has taken a beating. To continue in service, it needs new tires and a suspension upgrade. We want to raise funds to repair Steve's truck so that it can travel the high country for many years to come. Steve is one of the few people who take the time and effort to visit these men where they camp; if he were unable to get to them, he would be missed.

story:
Thank you for considering contributing to this endeavor... of creating a home where a girl can blossom like a beautiful lotus. 

When I first visited the Philippines, I saw very little hope. I saw street children, I saw orphans, I saw girls who didn't believe they had any value. I met kids who had never dreamed.  This is a sad reality for many children in the Philippines born into poverty. Poverty is everywhere. You can't hide from it. 

When you drive through Manila, children are begging, sleeping on the street in packs, going through the garbage in search of scraps.  It is the most shocking thing for any Westerner to witness. For Filipinos, it's normal every day life to witness this. Children have to work to make a few cents to help their families.  They're too poor to go to school.  It's not fair. 

5 years ago, I had a dream of building an orphanage. I wanted to educate and empower young girls to be the best they can in order to give back and help others. I don't believe in teaching them practical skills such as cooking and cleaning, I believe in higher education so that they can become leaders and not servants.  Am I too ambitious? Maybe.  But how can you change this pattern of poverty? 

Most of the children I met at orphanages come from families of 6-10 children. How can any family earn money to feed that many people? You can't. You simply cannot, which is why many of the children who are admitted into orphanages suffer from malnourishment. Again, this isn't fair. 

So to break this cycle, you have to focus on girls. Educate them about valuing themselves and giving back.  We want to give girls a chance so that they can lead the future and not just survive. 

Right now, we have 89 children sponsored in the Philippines. But we want to do more. We want to produce REAL results where our girls can go to a private university in Manila and excel, earn good salaries, and give back to the orphanage and inspire girls at the orphanage.  Is this a huge task? To some, maybe. But if you do this with the best of intentions and invest in these girls, I guarantee you'll have superstars... 

To learn about Maya's Hope, go to www.mayashope.org.

www.facebook.com/mayashope

www.twitter.com/mayashope


We have a dream that girls have limitless possibilities... so we want to give orphan girls the opportunity of an education and the tools to be successful strong women so that they can teach other young orphan girls how to be superstars too!

I met girls at orphanages who never had dreams. They never had hopes of a better life. I believe that if you nurture, encourage, and educate orphan girls, you can create superstars who can inspire other girls to succeed in life.  

I never want a girl to tell me that I was the first person to ever tell her she's smart and beautiful.  I want a girl to believe she is the best and can do anything she puts her mind to. Because she can.  That's my hope.

story:
Trovate il video e il testo in Italiano dopo il testo in Inglese.


We realized that all around us we see many negative, or not significant messages.

Then why not use this gap of communication to convey a positive and intelligent message, one that can help us remember who we really are?

"Don't forget who we are" is born precisely from this concept.


So, we have decided to tell the history of man on "pages of cloth" by recalling his most significant events, from tragic mistakes to stunning achievements: the steps taken by our species on the road that led us to become what we are today.

Lest we forget.

Not only a new line of t-shirts, but a project that aims not only to meet the aesthetic tastes of consumers, but to draw their attention towards a content of a strong social significance.

On the front of our t-shirts, which have been entirely produced in Italy, there will be an image of an event or a character that, for better or worse, with honour or horror, has left an indelible mark on history.



And there's more: an image and a slogan can convey an emotion, maybe a fleeting one, but they can also leave a mark if they become the stimulus to search for more information. 

That's why we have printed on the neck a QR Code that through any device connected to the Internet, such as a smartphone, propels us straight to the details of that story.



And then under the image, on the left, we printed the Brand and our exhortation to remember : "Don't Forget Who We Are", let's not forget who we are and where we come from.



The subjects

The first stories that we decided to tell are 4 stories that we must not forget, because their protagonists have left a very strong message.


1) Martin Luther King


2) Mother Teresa


3) Birkenau



4) Enola Gay


The t-shirts

Among the shirts you can choose:

Women

1) Vest Tank top, 2) Tank Top

Off white  100% cotton slub

1) Tank top

 

2) Tank Top


Man

T-Shirt

Off white 100% cotton slub

 


 


On this site you will be able to fund our idea, to get the numbered and limited edition t-shirt, to be our "ambassadors" and to suggest new stories to tell.

To choose the sizes, the characters and models you can write on info@dontforgetwwa.com


Why we need your support?

Reaching the target of $ 55,000 will allow us to give life to the first phase of our project:

· perks development and distribution ;

· Production of the first line of t-shirts to be sold on line;

· web marketing campaign;

· Provide an e-commerce platform; the only distribution channel.


Stretch goals

With your support, you will give us the opportunity to reach more ambitious goals. with:

85,000 $  - We can create new topics. Thanks to you we can tell new stories in the Don't Forget way.

125,000 $- New collection. New models and colors.

360,000 $ - Something Special! We will produce the new t-shirt child line, full of stories and educational simple rules for the little ones.


Suggestions

What stories would you like to be told in the "Don't Forget" way?

Write on info@dontforgetwwa.com and suggest stories that you most care about and that you believe should be told.

We will inform you on indiegogo.com on which ones are the most popular.


(Versione in Italiano)


Ognuno di noi nella nostra esteriorità trasmette messaggi; perché non veicolarne uno intelligente?



L'uomo è il solo essere vivente che indossa indumenti: un'altra delle caratteristiche uniche della nostra specie. È qualcosa che fa pensare….

L’idea da cui siamo partiti e che ognuno di noi, nella nostra esteriorità, trasmette dei messaggi, tante piccole informazioni che danno agli altri un’idea di chi siamo e da dove proveniamo. Ci siamo accorti, che circolano per lo più messaggi negativi o poco significativi.

Allora ci siamo chiesti, perché non colmare questo vuoto comunicativo per farci portatori di un messaggio positivo, intelligente e che ci aiuti a ricordarci chi siamo veramente?

Il Brand: “Don't Forget Who We Are” nasce proprio da qui.

Così, abbiamo deciso di raccontare la storia dell’uomo su “pagine di stoffa”, richiamandone gli eventi più significativi, dai tragici errori alle meravigliose conquiste: i passi percorsi dalla nostra specie sulla strada che ci ha portato a diventare ciò che siamo oggi.

Per non dimenticare.Non solo una nuova linea di t-shirt, ma un progetto che ha lo scopo di andare incontro ai gusti estetici dei consumatori, e soprattutto di attirare l’attenzione di questi, verso contenuti ricchi di un forte significato.




Un’immagine può trasmettere un’emozione, magari fugace, ma può anche lasciare il segno se si trasforma in uno stimolo per saperne di più.

È per questo motivo che sul collo abbiamo aggiunto, oltre al titolo e alla data dell’evento, un QR Code che grazie a qualunque dispositivo collegato in rete, ci proietta all'interno di una storia che aiuta a comprendere l'essenza di quell'evento.

And there's more: an image and a slogan can convey an emotion, maybe a fleeting one, but they can also leave a mark if they become the stimulus to search for more information. 

That's why we have printed on the neck a QR Code that through any device connected to the Internet, such as a smartphone, propels us straight to the details of that story.


Sotto l'immagine, sulla sinistra, abbiamo riportato, il Marchio e la nostra esortazione a ricordare: “Don’t Forget Who We Are”, non dimentichiamo chi siamo e da dove veniamo.

And then under the image, on the left, we printed the Brand and our exhortation to remember : "Don't Forget Who We Are", let's not forget who we are and where we come from.


Le storie

The first stories that we decided to tell are 4 stories that we must not forget, because their protagonists have left a very strong message.

1) Martin Luther King


2) Mother Teresa


3) Birkenau



4) Enola Gay


Le t-shirts

Tra le maglie sarà possibile scegliere:

Donna

1) Fratino, 2) Canottiera

Off white  100% cotone fiammato 1) Fratin 

1) canottiera

 

2) Fratino


Uomo

T-Shirt

Off white 100% cotone fiammato

 


 

Su questo sito avrete la possibilità di finanziare la nostra idea, di ricevere le t-shirt numerate in edizione limitata, di essere i nostri "ambasciatori" e di suggerire nuove storie da raccontare.

Per scegliere le taglie, i soggetti ed i modelli potete scriverci su info@dontforgetwwa.com


Perché abbiamo bisogno del vostro supporto?

Raggiungere il target dei 55.000 $ ci permetterà di dar vita alla prima fase del nostro progetto:

· realizzazione e distribuzione dei perks/ricompensa;

· produzione delle prima linea di t-shirt da mettere in vendita;

· attuare una prima campagna di web marketing;

· realizzare una piattaforma di e-commerce, unico canale di distribuzione scelto.


Ulteriori Obiettivi

Con il vostro supporto, potremo raggiungere obiettivi più ambiziosi:

85.000 $  - Potremo realizzare nuovi soggetti. Grazie a voi possiamo raccontare nuove storie nella Don't Forget way.

125.000 $ – Nuova collezione. Nuovi modelli e colori.

360.000 $ - Qualcosa di speciale! Produrremo la linea bambini, ricca di storie e regole educative semplici per i più piccoli.


Suggerimenti

Quali storie ti piacerebbe fossero raccontate? 

Scrivici a info@dontforgetwwa.com e proponi le storie che ti stanno più a cuore e che ritieni debbano essere raccontate nella Don't Forget way.

Vi terremo aggiornati pubblicando la classifica delle vostre preferenze.

story:
"Be The Change You Wish To See In The World"


Hey angels. My name is Shannon O'Bryan and I am gearing up for a new adventure that will not only be life-changing for me, but is sure to create a ripple effect that will make an enormous impact in the world. I am launching this campaign in the hopes of raising money to help me to travel to India to volunteer for a company that has been doing some incredible work called ASTEP (Artists Striving To End Poverty). Once in India, working with the ASTEP team, I will work with a large group of children living in poverty in Pune and help them find their voices through the arts (dance, singing, acting, music, painting, creative writing, etc.) and teach them how to pay this service forward in their community. Without the help of ASTEP and Teach for India, these children may not have the opportunity to receive any education. Through our programs, these children are supported with schooling through high school and are prepared to move forward with their education or to head out into the work force creating tremendous positive change for them and their families. We do several community outreach projects while there, working to provide happiness, better health and an overall sense of peace for those living in an extremely challenged state. Our hope is to remove the underlying fear that exists in these poverty stricken areas, eventually bringing peace one town at a time around the world. 

Once my time in India is completed and I return to the States, I fully intend to continue this work and to support this wonderful organization here in the U.S. and in other countries all over the world. I know my time in India will be such a learning experience- and hopefully the beginning of the building of that Arts and Healing Center of my dreams;) 

What is Needed & What Are the Perks?

While in India, I am committing myself as a volunteer, which means, for the most part, I am giving up all sources of income for an extended period of time. Please help me to make this dream a reality. I will be living very simply and, if you know me, you know that I don't need for much.  

What is needed for a 6 month stay (I may stay longer, but we shall see… Don't worry mom and dad, I will try to make it home for Christmas;):

  • Travel Expenses: $1500
  • Housing/Food/Emergency Money/Classes/Misc.: $6000

What is in it for you:

I am also a meditation teacher, dance teacher, acupressure/marma therapist and Ayurvedic Mentor and would like to offer my services for anyone who donates. Check out our Perks:)

The Impact

Access to the arts is essential to children’s academic and social success. "From improving reading comprehension to advancing creative thinking, from teaching problem solving to fostering collaboration, access to the arts brings about significant improvements in children’s educational and social development." 

We know how important it is for a child to find their voice and to learn how to express themselves. I know from experience about finding my voice through artistic expression and how healing it is to learn how to use it and to communicate my feelings and opinions either through my body in dance or through my mind in creative writing or my hands through painting or drawing, etc. 

"ASTEP’s programs are based on rigorous research that has demonstrated how arts education and empowerment programming can improve the lives of underserved children and youth. Beyond simply bolstering children’s capacity for self-expression, research shows that arts programming has significant positive impact on children’s educational attainment and social skills.

  • Dramatic enactments of stories or text promote reading comprehension and literacy.
  • Music education develops spatial reasoning skills needed for understanding and analyzing logical and mathematical concepts.
  • Both individual and multi-arts learning experiences strengthen fundamental cognitive capacities such as conditional reasoning, problem-solving, and creative thinking.
  • Studies of student learning experiences in drama, music, dance and multi-arts activities show student growth in self-confidence, self-control, self-identity, conflict resolution, and collaboration."
As a teacher of meditation and yoga and other healing modalities and as a professional performing artist it became clear to me that it was my purpose in this world to marry together my love for the arts, teaching, healing and service. It is my mission to cultivate creative expression, help to provide an education to folks all over the world no matter what conditions they find themselves in, raise the level of awareness and happiness in the world and raise a new generation of children into their full power as humans and fully prepare them to speak out and heal this world of ours. I know…I dream BIG! It takes an incredible team, but let's build one and make it happen<3


Risks & Challenges

Giving service and building community are key for me and one of the challenges that comes along with this is simply finding the support financially to be able to share this passion and make it happen. It will take money to survive over there, but I know this is part of my path and so I know nature will support. All funds not used for basic living expenses and travel will be re-donated to the organizations I will be volunteering for over there. Thank you so much for your contribution… I can't begin to describe what it means to me. Any amount will mean the world to us and your support speaks louder than any dollar amount. I love you all so deeply. We are all in this together and it is our responsibility to help this world move in the way of progressive change and support one another in any way that we can to do so. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I totally understand if you just don't have the means at the moment to be able to contribute… heck, I wouldn't be launching this campaign if I didn't know what that was like ;) If it is just not a good time for you to subsidize a mission like this monetarily, but you would still like to contribute in some way:

    • Share this campaign with all of your friends and loved ones through your social networks.
    • Organize a group that would like to learn to meditate and I will teach on donation using all of the proceeds for this campaign. 
    • Send people my way for body work treatments or retreats happening over the next couple of months. 

    I am hoping to make it to India in October. Help me make this dream a reality. I will keep you posted on all of our progress and will be running a blog during my time over there so that you can see where your money has gone and what a huge impact you have made on these children's lives. 

    I am eternally grateful for all of you and love each and every one of you so deeply.

    Be Love. Be Light. Be.

    ~ Shannon O'Bryan

    www.sundarameditation.com
story_txt:
"Be The Change You Wish To See In The World"

Hey angels. My name is Shannon O'Bryan and I am gearing up for a new adventure that will not only be life-changing for me, but is sure to create a ripple effect that will make an enormous impact in the world. I am launching this campaign in the hopes of raising money to help me to travel to India to volunteer for a company that has been doing some incredible work called ASTEP (Artists Striving To End Poverty). Once in India, working with the ASTEP team, I will work with a large group of children living in poverty in Pune and help them find their voices through the arts (dance, singing, acting, music, painting, creative writing, etc.) and teach them how to pay this service forward in their community. Without the help of ASTEP and Teach for India, these children may not have the opportunity to receive any education. Through our programs, these children are supported with schooling through high school and are prepared to move forward with their education or to head out into the work force creating tremendous positive change for them and their families. We do several community outreach projects while there, working to provide happiness, better health and an overall sense of peace for those living in an extremely challenged state. Our hope is to remove the underlying fear that exists in these poverty stricken areas, eventually bringing peace one town at a time around the world. 
Once my time in India is completed and I return to the States, I fully intend to continue this work and to support this wonderful organization here in the U.S. and in other countries all over the world. I know my time in India will be such a learning experience- and hopefully the beginning of the building of that Arts and Healing Center of my dreams;)    What is Needed & What Are the Perks? While in India, I am committing myself as a volunteer, which means, for the most part, I am giving up all sources of income for an extended period of time. Please help me to make this dream a reality. I will be living very simply and, if you know me, you know that I don't need for much.  
What is needed for a 6 month stay (I may stay longer, but we shall see… Don't worry mom and dad, I will try to make it home for Christmas;):


Travel Expenses: $1500

Housing/Food/Emergency Money/Classes/Misc.: $6000

What is in it for you:
I am also a meditation teacher, dance teacher, acupressure/marma therapist and Ayurvedic Mentor and would like to offer my services for anyone who donates. Check out our Perks:)

It will take money to survive over there, but I know this is part of my path and so I know nature will support. Thank you so much for your contribution… I can't begin to describe what it means to me. Any amount will mean the world to us and your support speaks louder than any dollar amount. I love you all so deeply. We are all in this together and it is our responsibility to help this world move in the way of progressive change and support one another in any way that we can to do so.

Send people my way for body work treatments or retreats happening over the next couple of months. 

I am hoping to make it to India in October. Help me make this dream a reality. I will keep you posted on all of our progress and will be running a blog during my time over there so that you can see where your money has gone and what a huge impact you have made on these children's lives.

story:
Short Summary

Botshabelo, meaning “a place of refuge” in Sotho, is an orphanage in Magliesburg, South Africa that shelters, clothes, feeds, educates, and provides medical care and love to children infected or affected by HIV/AIDS. Deeply influenced by the economic disparity between blacks and whites during Apartheid and the forced breakdown of black families, the Cloete’s gave up their comfortable upper middle class life to found this organization. In addition to providing the children with everything they need to survive, the Cloetes love and care for them as their own. Every week, new orphans arrive needing refuge and affection, and others are tragically lost. Throughout, they do the best they can to give these children a chance at life that they would not otherwise have.

Visiting Botshabelo and aiding them was one of the most significant experiences of our lives. The intelligence and compassion of these children shone through their difficult circumstances. Arriving back in the United States, we hope to aid them in whatever way we can. With your help, we will construct a classroom to further their education and help them rise above their difficult childhoods.

What We Need

Our goal is to adopt a classroom at Bothshabelo. This will include furnishing, tiling, decorating, roofing, and installing a class toilet and shower. This is an expensive task, but it is also the best way to permanently improve these children's circumstances. 

    The Impact

    Providing these necessary, humanitarian services to these children is an extremely costly endeavor, especially under a government rife with corruption and greed. The number of children they care for is constantly increasing, and because they live by the traditional value ubuntu, they never turn away those in need, whether it be a child, adult or even animal. With their increasing numbers space is becoming an issue, and that is where we want your help. 

    The Cloetes are doing everything they can to provide the kids at Botshabelo with the best education possible, but their lack of space and resources makes it difficult. A new classroom will give them the room and materials they need to expand their program and further support the children's growth and development. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Constructing and furnishing a classroom takes a lot of time, money and resources. It is possible that we will not be able to raise enough money to actually succeed in completing this project. However, regardless of whether or not we collect enough to build the classroom, one hundred percent of your donations will be used to provide and care for these children. Food and clothes are always needed, as well as classroom supplies. Each donation will make a meaningful impact in these children's lives. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Thank you for viewing our campaign. While the building of a classroom at Botshabelo is our goal, our greater desire is to help these children in any way we can. The more awareness that is generated about the children at Botshabelo, the more people will be inspired to help. Please share their story with your friends and loved ones. You can find more information about the orphanage and other ways you can help at www.botshabelo.org

story:
« Depuis tout petit mes parents m'ont poussé à lire j'ai donc grandi dans un univers où la lecture était partout, elle m'a permis d'apprendre et de me cultiver, mais par dessus tout le livre m'a permis de rêver. Le constat que nous avons fait au sein de l'association Tchiley est qu'un bon nombre d'enfants défavorisés n'ont pas la chance que nous avons eu de posséder un livre ils se voient donc priver de tout ce que le livre nous a apporté. Les actions de l'association Tchiley ont pour objectif de permettre à ces enfants d'avoir la même chance que nous avons eue, celle de vivre entourer de livre.

Nandjui Joel-Armel Président Association TCHILEY

Notre vision "Tout enfant a droit au rêve"

L'association TCHILEY est née de la volonté de faire de cette phrase une réalité. Nous sommes un groupe de jeunes pour la plupart étudiants originaires de la Côte d’Ivoire qui veulent rendre témoignage de l’amour de Dieu en agissant en faveur des enfants défavorisés en leur permettant de rêver en insérant le livre dans leur quotidien.

L’association TCHILEY, qui veut dire « ENFANT » en Dida , une ethnie de l’ouest de la Côte d’Ivoire, est née du désir de rendre donc accessible aux enfants moins privilégiés la part de rêve et d'épanouissement que peut revêtir un roman, un essai, un recueil de poèmes ou encore un livre de contes. Son objectif est donc de participer à l’éveil et de favoriser l'accès à la culture des enfants défavorisés à travers l'outil livre.


Nos projets

L'association TCHILEY met en place deux projets :

L'opération Mékangan Flouanou :

L'opération« MEKANGAN FLOUANOU » signifie « ILS LISENT » en Baoulé une ethnie du centre de la Côte d'Ivoire. L'objectif de cette opération est d'organiser une journée récréative avec une structure d’accueil pour enfants défavorisés à qui nous offrirons un spectacle de contes, une bibliothèque plein de livres et des vivres.

Pour cette deuxième édition de l’opération MEKANGAN FLOUANOU qui aura lieu le samedi 2 Aout , nous avons choisi la fondation Hirondelles, située à Attoban, dans la commune de Cocody à Abidjan.

La fondation a été créée fin décembre 2007. L’initiative est née du constat qu’il existait une grande précarité autour de ce secteur que l’on peut qualifier de « huppé ».

La fondation Hirondelles se définit comme un centre d’accueil et de formation de base.

Ce centre accueille pour cette année 107 enfants, la plupart orphelins sous la tutelle d'un proche. Leur âge varie de 6 à 16 ans et ils viennent essentiellement de Gobelet (bidonville du quartier Attoban). Le dit centre dispense également des cours de la classe de CP1 à la classe de CM1.

Le projet A Zêré :

Le projet A Zêré qui signifie « LISEZ » en Bété, une ethnie du sud ouest de la Côte d'Ivoire, a pour objectif de venir en complément de l'opération Mékangan flouanou. Au cours du projet A Zêré nous souhaitons organiser des ateliers de lecture. Ces ateliers seront constitués de mini-activités ludiques qui auront pour but de faire découvrir le livres aux enfants dans la durée. L’objectif de ces ateliers est de familiariser les enfants avec l'outil livre. Cette année le projet A Zêrè se déroulera avec les enfants du centre Hirondelles et se déroulera une fois par mois à partir du mois de septembre 2014. Un animateur professionnel sera en charge de l'animation de ces ateliers. A travers ce projet nous voulons favoriser l'accès à la culture de ces enfants à travers le livre et ainsi leur permettre de construire leur avenir sur des bases solides.

Le projet « Mékangan flouanou » vise à faire entrer le livre dans le monde des enfants le projet« A Zêré » vise lui à le faire y rester.


Nos besoins

Pour mener à bien nos deux projets nous avons besoin de votre aide. La somme recueillie grâce à cette campagne de dons servira aux financements de l'opération Mekangan flouanou et des ateliers de contes A Zêré

Pour l'opération Mekangan flouanou l'argent récolté servira au financement du spectacle de conte qui sera animé par une compagnie de conte professionnelle située à Abidjan. Lors de cette journée, l'association TCHILEY offrira un repas à tous les enfants du centre. Une partie de cette collecte sera donc allouée au financement de ce repas. Le livre tient une place importante dans notre projet c'est pourquoi nous envisageons d'utiliser l'argent récolté pour acheter des livres que nous offrirons de manière individuelle à chaque enfant. Des vivres seront également achetés avec l'argent récolté, ces vivres permettrons au centre de subvenir aux besoins des enfants.

Pour le projet A Zêré, un animateur professionnel sera engagé par l'association pour animer les ateliers. La rémunération de celui-ci sera la dépense principale de ce projet.

L'association Tchiley a besoin de votre aide pour apporter de la joie dans la vie de ces petits enfants. En donnant soyez le soleil qui illuminera leur cœur!

« un peu de nous c'est déjà beaucoup pour eux »


Nous aider autrement

Si vous partagez la vision de l'association TCHILEY mais que vous n'avez pas la possibilité de faire un don, Vous pouvez quand même nous aider en partageant autour de vous notre projet car pour atteindre notre objectif nous avons besoin de toucher un maximum de personnes.

Pour ceux qui souhaitent participer à la réalisation de nos projets en mettant à profit leurs compétences n'hésitez pas à devenir Ambassadeur TCHILEY en cliquant sur le lien. https://docs.google.com/forms/d/10fbXtZlQfskYJUl4G_-kST2F8vScAOmEuRHvipv8ajs/viewform

Merci pour votre aide et n'oubliez pas qu'il y a plus de joie à donner qu'à recevoir

story:
Most attacks begin with a conversation. 

Not all conversations lead to an attack.

How do you know when a conversation is going to go bad?


My Story

My name is Michelle Gay. I am a 5th degree black belt, 5-time women’s full contact fighting champion, a Laban Certified Movement Analyst and martial arts instructor at Ken Wa Kan Karate in NYC. A close friend was raped by a man she met at a hockey rink, he offered to drive her home – she was fifteen. Her life was altered forever. Mine too, although, I didn’t realize it at the time.

1 in 4 woman and 1 in 7 men with be sexually assaulted in their lifetime, and many before they reach the age of 20.  As a trained advocate for the St. Vincent Rape Crisis Program from 1996 – 2002, I discovered that most sexual assault begins with some form of "getting to know you" - an offer to help in some way, a request for assistance from you, or an offer to do something for you, like buy you a drink or dinner. 

In 2003, combining martial arts, movement analysis and verbal communication techniques, I developed the Safe and Sound Seminar.  I have taught it at Barnard College, Baruch College, Lehman College, Dalton High School and for the last 8 years as part of Broadway Dance Center’s International Foreign Student Visa Program.  I continue to offer it frequently at The Society for Martial Arts Instruction in NYC, but I want to make this life-saving education available to a large number of people. 

It's time to make it available globally by putting it online as a web tutorial!  Easily digestible segments that can be downloaded on your computer or phone and played on the way to a party, before you travel or on your way to a date.  Ultimately our goal is to have you and your loved ones making informed and empowered decisions so they can be safe and sound wherever they are.

You can make this project a reality by contributing money and joining our Safe and Sound community of street smart warriors.    No matter what your level of participation, we welcome you to take action, especially if you think this seminar would be valuable to your friends, family and communities.  The fact that you read all the way to the end of this, speaks volumes to the commitment that you are to people being safe and sound.

In service and gratitude, 

Michelle Gay and the SASS Team



About The Seminar

The seminar begins with a scenario of a man picking up a woman at a party.  We break down the conversation that leads up to an attack and teach people the cues to look for when someone is trying to dominate you.  

We then do movement exercises to look at some of the body language and non-verbal elements of domination.  You learn techniques for being smart on the street and gain awareness about your own behavior.  Attackers are often working hard to get you off balance by speeding you up, slowing you down or confusing you.  We teach you how to be powerful in your space and understand your own strengths and weaknesses. 

We end the seminar with a little butt kicking, so that participants walk away with some easy physical self defense to back up the word "No."  Release and run techniques, where to hit sensitive areas on the body and tips for getting away will give you the tools you need if things get hairy.

For a more in-depth look at the course, you can watch this video:

Standing up to an Epidemic of Violence with Education

Assault continues to be a huge problem, especially on college campuses.  In a recent article from Rolling Stone entitled "Confronting Campus Rape" President Obama said, "Now it's up to each of us – every single one of us – to keep up this momentum. We've got to keep working with educators and police officers to search for new ways to prevent these crimes. We are going to keep pushing for people to step up across my administration, in state capitals and on college campuses across the country. And perhaps most importantly, we need to keep saying to anyone out there who has ever been assaulted: You are not alone. We have your back."

Many leaders talk about "preventing violence" but don't provide enough security or education to support communities in being safe.  Ultimately we must be responsible for our safety and the safety of those around us.  Don't let your friend go off with with a stranger, get to know the person you are about to let into your building and ultimately, trust your gut.

We see the Safe and Sound Seminar as a powerful tool that has you spot a potential predator or bully, disarm them with your words and get you to safety.  Not every good samaritan is a criminal and not every charming guy is Prince Charming.  We can help you tell the difference.


Our Goals

We hope to make this online tutorial available to schools, colleges, businesses and organizations across the country.  We think this seminar is especially valuable to young people who are moving away from home for the fist time and may be moving to a city where assault and theft are more common.  We would like to see this course offered as part of every orientation packet in colleges across the globe.

The funds we raise will be used to film my lecture and a scenario we will film with a professional team of filmmakers led by Producer/Director Laura Newman.  Zelda is co-writer and fight choreographer for the scene.  Funds will also go toward creating a website and marketing materials so we can reach the widest amount of people possible.  

Once we have made parts 1-3 we plan to sell them online and to organizations, building up enough funds to create parts 4-10.  We plan to film more scenarios that appeal to a diverse range of people; men who may be concerned with bullying or mugging, LGBT people, children, etc.  Ultimately we want the course to be accessible and valuable to anyone.


Testmonials

“As Director of Educational Programming at Broadway Dance Center, I am delighted to wholeheartedly endorse Michelle Gay’s “Safe And Sound” Seminar. I highly recommend the class for anyone who wants to feel more empowered and aware!” - Bonnie Ericson - Broadway Dance Center-Director of Educational Programming

“Michelle Gay taught a Safe And Sound Seminar to my dance students at Lehman College. The next class they were bubbling over with excitement and couldn’t stop talking about it. They were amazed by how clear and specific and simple the information was. They kept talking about the videos and the movements they’d worked on together. Every student, male and female, seemed to have gotten something from the class that they would take out into their lives immediately. They also loved Michelle as a person; they were quite inspired by her combination of strength and tenderness and left wanting more!” - Aynsley Vandenbroucke-Adjunct Professor

"[The attack] wouldn't have happened if I'd had these tools from the Safe and Sound Seminar.  That's why I want to share about this and share about my experience so other woman can benefit from it.  This is a seminar that will be really valuable to you and I believe has given me the tools to save my own life.  That whatever happened in the past is not going to go down again cause I have these tools now." - Mariposa - student of the Safe and Sound Seminar


How you can participate!

  • Sign up for tutorial or attend the live seminar in NYC!
  • Call you school or alma mater and asks them to make this available!  We are offering a 2 year license to institutions so they can make the online tutorials available to all their staff and students.
  • Share this on your social media!
  • Talk to us!  We welcome your ideas and support.

Thank you!
story_txt:
Most attacks begin with a conversation. 
Not all conversations lead to an attack.
How do you know when a conversation is going to go bad?
My StoryMy name is Michelle Gay. I am a 5th degree black belt, 5-time women’s full
contact fighting champion, a Laban Certified Movement Analyst and martial arts instructor at Ken Wa Kan Karate in NYC. A close friend was raped by a man she met at a hockey rink, he offered to drive
her home – she was fifteen. Her life was altered forever. Mine too, although, I
didn’t realize it at the time.
1 in 4 woman and 1 in 7 men with be sexually assaulted in their lifetime, and many before they reach the age of 20.  As a trained advocate for the St. Vincent Rape Crisis Program
from 1996 – 2002, I discovered that most sexual assault begins with some form
of "getting to know you" - an offer to help in some way, a request for assistance
from you, or an offer to do something for you, like buy you a drink or dinner. 
In 2003, combining martial arts, movement analysis and verbal communication techniques, I developed the Safe and Sound
Seminar.  I have taught it at Barnard College, Baruch College, Lehman College, Dalton High School and for the last 8 years as part of Broadway Dance Center’s International Foreign Student Visa Program.  I continue to offer it frequently at The Society for Martial Arts Instruction in NYC, but I want to make this life-saving education available to a large number of people. It's time to make it available globally by putting it online as a web tutorial!  Easily digestible segments that can be downloaded on your computer or phone and
played on the way to a party, before you travel or on your way to a date.  Ultimately our goal is to have you and your loved ones making
informed and empowered decisions so they can be safe and sound wherever they are.
You can make this project a reality by
contributing money and joining our Safe and Sound community of street smart warriors.    No matter what your level of participation, we welcome you to take action, especially if you think this seminar would be valuable to your friends, family and communities.  The fact that you read all the way to the end of this, speaks volumes to the commitment that

story:
El Nahual is a small community centre and school straddled between urban and rural areas in the Western Highlands of Guatemala. We were founded in 2004 and our mission is to provide free or extremely low-cost education to the under-served communities on the edge of the city.

Why Focus on Education in Guatemala?

Due to a history of civil war, racism, and corruption, many children do not get the opportunity to even attend primary school. Many families do not see the value of investing in a child's education. Because of this, the literacy rate in Guatemala is only 55%. Even the families that can see value in educating their children are unable to assist their children in their studies being unable to read themselves. Partner this fact with the public school system that places up to 35 elementary school children in a class and up to 50 middle school aged children, and you can see why many children simply do not succeed. On top of that, it is a financial burden to send children to school after paying for uniforms and books (which can't be reused since children do their work directly in the textbooks). The poverty in some areas is so overwhelming that parents pull their children out of school quite early to work. Schools often fail to properly identify and cater to students with learning disabilities, which leads these children to drop out early because of a lack of options. Because of these factors, an estimated half of all children in Guatemala drop out of school before finishing their primary education in sixth grade.

Our goal is to provide a solution to families and people who want to study and can't afford it, and to emphasize the importance of education within the community.

Our Current Programs and School

Right now in El Nahual, we offer six programs on-site and one off-site. Several of these programs are registered with the Ministry of Education. These six programs are offered in our school building which is comprised of five classrooms and one larger room, in addition to the kitchen and offices. We also offer Spanish classes to foreigners, which help fund our community education initiatives.

Our programs include:

  • Manos de Colores (Colored Hands) is an after school and vacation program for children in primary school. Children have access to a trained Guatemalan teacher to help with their homework and to reinforce weak areas of study. They also receive additional classes in art, English, theatre, and teamwork with foreign and local volunteers. Children also receive a small snack since some of the children in the area may not get lunch. Currently we have 30 – 40 children showing up every day, double the amount of last year, with new children signing up every week.

  • Primeria Acelerada (Accelerated Primary) is a program designed for learners older than 14 years old to finish first through sixth grade on Saturdays. A student can expect to finish the entire program start to finish in two years. Last year, we had 12 graduates of this program, and this year we have 32 students enrolled. In the next year, we expect these numbers to continue growing.

  • Educación Básica (Basic Education) is secondary education, the equivalent of seventh through ninth grade. This is a new program that we started offering this year to teens. Students study in the afternoons on school days. As a new program, we are only offering the first year (Primero Básico or seventh grade) and will begin offer the second year (Segundo Básico or eighth grade) next year. There are eight students currently enrolled in this program.

  • Educación Básica for adults over 18 years of age is offered on Sundays. This is also a new program and we currently have seven students enrolled.

  • Bachillerato is the equivalent of high school. We are offering this at night from six until nine on weekdays. This is also a new program of this year and we currently have three students enrolled.

  • English classes are open to the whole community. The majority of students are teens and young adults trying to open up new work opportunities. These classes are taught by foreign volunteers and are flexible depending on the students and teachers.

  • Our seventh, off-site program is in local public schools. When there are enough volunteers, we send them to teach English classes in the schools to help fulfill the curriculum requirement to schools that simply don't have money to hire a qualified English teacher.

Future Plans

Because of our growing popularity in the community and rising enrollment, we have plans to start offering several new programs.

In the next year, we would like to offer regular primary school for children in addition to our after school program. We are also interested in having a free daycare centre so that mothers in the community are freer to work or study in order to improve their family economy.

In order to accommodate growth in our current programs and to be able to provide additional programs, we need to expand our physical building. We have purchased a 200-square-metre piece of land adjacent to the school with the help of a grant and are planning to build 6 – 8 classrooms and a play area for the children. We have worked out a budget to fence off the land and build the first level of classrooms (4 classrooms – two on each side). In the future we may construct a second level of classrooms, however this is not included in the current budget.

This is our current budget of funds for work materials for the project:

  • 3 concrete walls to fence off the area (10m, 12.6m, 24m x 3.8m high) – Q103,305 ($13,416.23 USD)

  • 4 concrete calls to serve as dividers between classrooms (5m each x 3.8m high) – Q25,000 ($3,246.75 USD)

  • Wooden beams to support roof (40) – Q20,000 ($2,597.40 USD)

  • Tin corrugated roofing – Q10,000 ($1,298.70 USD)

  • Metal doors (4) – Q6,000 ($779.20 USD)

  • Metal windowframes (4) – Q4,000 ($519.48 USD)

  • Wood for ceilings – Q5,000 ($649.35 USD)

  • Electrical – Q7,000 ($909.09 USD)

Total: Q180,000 ($23,376.00 USD)

Please note that the exchange rate used is 7.7Q per USD and is subject to fluctuations.

As you can see, the project will end up costing twice the amount of what we are requesting. Additional funds not obtained through this fundraiser would come from income raised by the Spanish school and from loans.

Who Are the People We Help?

We'd like to share with you two stories:

José and his sister Heidi attend Manos de Colores every afternoon. Their parents do not know how to read or write. They also have a younger sister who they take with them to the school although she is too young for the program – there is nobody at home to look after her. José is 12 and has special needs. The public school refuses to accept him. Although what we can do for him is very little, we think that it is important that he feel accepted in the school and that he learn basic math skills and reading. Heidi is 9 and is enrolled in first grade for the third time. Her mother is desperate because she fears that next year she will not be able to afford for her to repeat the grade again. Heidi struggles a lot with reading and writing and here she receives one-on-one support from a local teacher who can help her succeed this year. We hope that their younger sister will eventually have the opportunity to attend school as well and to succeed. We are definitely ready to support and assist her in whatever she needs!

Juan Pedro started not by studying, but by working at El Nahual as a maintenance worker when he was a teenager. He had not yet finished his schooling, but used the job to support his secondary education, which he completed on Sundays. He supported us in our community projects, which at the time included an organic garden where local women could grow food to support their families. After finishing his studies, he started to work with us as a Spanish teacher for foreign students, continuing to support us in our community projects. During his time as a Spanish teacher, he also attended university. Now, he is a Math teacher and comes and helps us in Manos de Colores in school break in order to reach children in the area and inspire them to complete their studies like he did. Although he didn't study with us, Juan Pedro is a shining example of what a person can acheive when they see the value in education, and he continues to be a welcome part of our community.

When our new school building is built, we will be able to serve and support more children and more families in education. We will be able to help children like Heidi finish their education and find a profession like Juan did. Please help support us in realizing this dream for the children and families in the communities of Quetzaltenango!

Other Ways You Can Make a Difference

We very much appreciate your support with our project! If you are unable to give right now, there are a few other ways that you can help. We always welcome Spanish students, who support our program through the fees they pay and by their volunteer work. We also welcome volunteers who have more than three weeks to offer and a basic to intermediate level of Spanish to help teach classes and provide administrative and promotional support. If none of these things are possible for you, we would really appreciate you simply sharing the word! Share the link to this page or to our website – maybe someone you know could help us out as well! We thank you very much for your interest in El Nahual.

Please see our website www.languageselnahual.com for more information, or send your questions and comments to our Coordinators at cdl.elnahual@gmail.com

El Nahual extends you a very big THANK YOU for your interest!

story:
Friends and Family,

I’m graduating from Western Washington University this June!  I managed to graduate on time in four years, with a major in Cultural Anthropology and a certificate/minor in TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages).  As the graduation deadline gets closer, it makes me reflect on how much I accomplished, learned, and experienced in such a short amount of time; as well as become anxious to start the new chapter of my life!  I’d like to say I know my exact career path, but I can’t yet.  What I can say is, I’m ready to apply my degree with hands on experience this summer.

For my last two quarters, I have been working with Trish Skillman, the director of the TESOL program at WWU, and Steven Vanderstaay, the Vice Provo of Undergraduate Education, Professor of English, and director of the collaborative international service-learning project, Building Bridges in Rwanda. 

Building Bridges in Rwanda is focused on helping the citizens of Gashora.  One of their top requests from our program is English instruction in the local health center.

Rwanda's community health system is well known as one of the best in Africa. In ten short years, Rwanda has drastically reduced rates of AIDs, Malaria, malnutrition and other infectious diseases. The heroes in this effort are the community health workers who travel by foot or bicycle to the rural communities, who I will be working with.

With English recently becoming a national language in Rwanda, the medicine labels and medical training materials are printed in English. Yet most health workers don't speak English. That's why service projects like this, which provide English instruction for community health workers, are so crucial.

Americans are very welcome in Rwanda. The community health center I will be teaching in was built with aid from the United States. With your help, I can help make the center even more effective by teaching the health workers English.  Steven went to Gashora in February with some of the materials I created and came back with an outstanding review of how beneficial it was to the health workers.

Here is a section of an email from Steven:

"We provided ESL instruction at the Health Center for 4 days. I taught material that reviewed the curriculum we taught at the health center last summer and a packet of material that you created for us. The students appreciated my review but were thrilled by the curricula you provided. Your health-related English materials were very culturally appropriate and at a level that worked for the health workers.

The health workers were also very pleased with the laminated flash cards you provided; they have added these to their library so that students can use them and check them out.

The health workers were very excited about the possibility that you could provide a curricula of 4 weeks of health-related English materials for them in the summer.”

Currently, I’m creating the 4-week curricula for the health center. 

With my expertise in TESOL and the program needing an extra hand in English instruction and management of the classroom, I have been asked to go on the program this summer as a WWU faculty member! This is a volunteer based program for myself, as I will be an alumnus from WWU.  The program is paying for my flight, but I have to pay for the rest of the trip.  The total cost of the trip is $1,500 for lodging, meals, service learning projects, travel/health insurance, and excursions and transportation in Rwanda. 

With your donation, you will be contributing to my future goals of becoming an ESL teacher as well as the passion I have for other cultures and travelling.  You will also be contributing to strengthening and sustaining Gashora’s community and people.

Everything that is fundraised will go directly to the program.  As little as $10 will be immensely helpful!  If I don’t reach my goal, I will pay for the rest out of pocket. 

I thank you for taking your time in reading this, and hope you consider donating to an opportunity that will be life changing and rewarding in so many ways. 

 

- Breanna 

 

The above picture is last year's group with the health workers.  Below is more information if you would like to learn more about the program, Rwanda, and the health center.

Link to WWU program information:

http://www.acadweb.wwu.edu/eesp/template/studyabroad/home_rwanda.shtml

The travel blog from last year’s group in the program:

http://rwandastudy2012.blogspot.com/

Gashora Health Center:

http://www.rwandaworks.com/projects/gashora-health-center

The World Bank – Rwanda:

http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/rwanda
story_txt:
Friends and Family,
I’m graduating from Western Washington University this June!  I managed to graduate on time in four years, with a major in Cultural Anthropology and a certificate/minor in TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages).  As the graduation deadline gets closer, it makes me reflect on how much I accomplished, learned, and experienced in such a short amount of time; as well as become anxious to start the new chapter of my life!  I’d like to say I know my exact career path, but I can’t yet.  What I can say is, I’m ready to apply my degree with hands on experience this summer.
For my last two quarters, I have been working with Trish Skillman, the director of the TESOL program at WWU, and Steven Vanderstaay, the Vice Provo of Undergraduate Education, Professor of English, and director of the collaborative international service-learning project, Building Bridges in Rwanda. 
Building Bridges in Rwanda is focused on helping the citizens of Gashora.  One of their top requests from our program is English instruction in the local health center.
Rwanda's community health system is well known as one of the best in Africa. In ten short years, Rwanda has drastically reduced rates of AIDs, Malaria, malnutrition and other infectious diseases. The heroes in this effort are the community health workers who travel by foot or bicycle to the rural communities, who I will be working with.  With English recently becoming a national language in Rwanda, the medicine labels and medical training materials are printed in English. Yet most health workers don't speak English. That's why service projects like this, which provide English instruction for community health workers, are so crucial. Americans are very welcome in Rwanda. The community health center I will be teaching in was built with aid from the United States. With your help, I can help make the center even more effective by teaching the health workers English.  Steven went to Gashora in February with some of the materials I created and came back with an outstanding review of how beneficial it was to the health workers.
Here is a section of an email from Steven:
"We provided ESL instruction at the Health Center for 4 days. I taught material that reviewed the curriculum we taught at the health center last summer and a packet of material that you created for us. The students appreciated my review but were thrilled by the curricula you provided. Your health-related English materials were very culturally appropriate and at a level that worked for the health workers.
The health workers were also very pleased with the laminated flash cards you provided; they have added these to their library so that students can use them and check them out.
The health workers were very excited about the possibility that you could provide a curricula of 4 weeks of health-related English materials for them in the summer.”
Currently, I’m creating the 4-week curricula for the health center. 
With my expertise in TESOL and the program needing an extra hand in English instruction and management of the classroom, I have been asked to go on the program this summer as a WWU faculty member! This is a volunteer based program for myself, as I will be an alumnus from WWU.  The program is paying for my flight, but I have to pay for the rest of the trip.  The total cost of the trip is $1,500 for lodging, meals, service learning projects, travel/health insurance, and excursions and transportation in Rwanda. 
With your donation, you will be contributing to my future goals of becoming an ESL teacher as well as the passion I have for other cultures and travelling.  You will also be contributing to strengthening and sustaining Gashora’s community and people.
Everything that is fundraised will go directly to the program.  As little as $10 will be immensely helpful!  If I don’t reach my goal, I will pay for the rest out of pocket. 
I thank you for taking your time in reading this, and hope you consider donating to an opportunity that will be life changing and rewarding in so many ways. 
 
- Breanna

http://rwandastudy2012.blogspot.com/

http://www.rwandaworks.com/projects/gashora-health-center
