story:
Our names are Hailey and Hayden Liddell and we are sixth graders at Burton Elementary in Kaysville, Utah.  We have been selected, in a statewide   competition involving more than 285 projects at regional and state levels, to   represent Utah at the National History Day Contest at the University of   Maryland, College Park, June 14-18 2014. As two delegates to this prestigious academic program, we are seeking support to represent our school and community in a delegation of Utahans at the national contest. National History Day (NHD) is a nationally acclaimed, academic enrichment program that   promotes the study of history in our schools. National History Day does for   history what the Science Fair does for science. Each year students like us   create exhibits, documentaries, performances, websites and papers about a   topic that is related to the annual NHD theme. This year’s theme is “Rights   and Responsibilities.” For our project, we created a website called, “The   Forgotten Guinea Pigs: The Downwinder’s story.”    Click on this link: http://20842327.nhd.weebly.com/  It chronicles the struggles of the   people living downwind (primarily Utahans) of the atomic blasts at the Nevada Test Site in the 1950’s.  We were   able to compete at the state level on April 23rd, and now we are in need of help to go on to the national contest. Our participation in the National History Day Contest depends on whether we can raise $2500 in sponsorships. The contest registration is $210. Contest housing is $675 and our travel to Washington, DC will be $1500.    Our contest costs must be paid no later than May 19, 2014. We strongly believe that attending the National History Day Contest will contribute to our education in a way few experiences can. The national contest is an   exceptional opportunity for us to hone our historical research, critical thinking and analytical skills while meeting with students from all across the United States as well as students from Guam, American Samoa and Europe. Having the opportunity to visit the nations capital and be surrounded by so much history, will be a life changing experience.  Your   support for our request would be greatly appreciated. If you would like further information about NHD, you can visit the Utah site which is http://utahhistoryfair.weebly.com/   or the national site at www.nhd.org or call the national office at   301-314-9739.

If you cannot personally help us financially, maybe you could help us by forwarding this site to anyone you know who might be interested.  We are trying to raise awareness of the plight of the Downwinder's.  If you know a downwinder, please let them about our cause.

If you chose to help us fund this trip, we will be forever greatful because this is a once in a life time experience we will never forget.
story_txt: Our names are Hailey and Hayden Liddell and we are sixth graders at Burton Elementary in Kaysville, Utah.  We have been selected, in a statewide   competition involving more than 285 projects at regional and state levels, to   represent Utah at the National History Day Contest at the University of   Maryland, College Park, June 14-18 2014. As two delegates to this prestigious academic program, we are seeking support to represent our school and community in a delegation of Utahans at the national contest. National History Day (NHD) is a nationally acclaimed, academic enrichment program that   promotes the study of history in our schools. National History Day does for   history what the Science Fair does for science. Each year students like us   create exhibits, documentaries, performances, websites and papers about a   topic that is related to the annual NHD theme. This year’s theme is “Rights   and Responsibilities.” For our project, we created a website called, “The   Forgotten Guinea Pigs: The Downwinder’s story.”    Click on this link: http://20842327.nhd.weebly.com/  It chronicles the struggles of the   people living downwind (primarily Utahans) of the atomic blasts at the Nevada Test Site in the 1950’s.  We were   able to compete at the state level on April 23rd, and now we are in need of help to go on to the national contest. Our participation in the National History Day Contest depends on whether we can raise $2500 in sponsorships. The contest registration is $210. Contest housing is $675 and our travel to Washington, DC will be $1500.    Our contest costs must be paid no later than May 19, 2014. We strongly believe that attending the National History Day Contest will contribute to our education in a way few experiences can. The national contest is an   exceptional opportunity for us to hone our historical research, critical thinking and analytical skills while meeting with students from all across the United States as well as students from Guam, American Samoa and Europe. Having the opportunity to visit the nations capital and be surrounded by so much history, will be a life changing experience.  Your   support for our request would be greatly appreciated. If you would like further information about NHD, you can visit the Utah site which is http://utahhistoryfair.weebly.com/   or the national site at www.nhd.org or call the national office at   301-314-9739.If you cannot personally help us financially, maybe you could help us by forwarding this site to anyone you know who might be interested.  We are trying to raise awareness of the plight of the Downwinder's.  If you know a downwinder, please let them about our cause.If you chose to help us fund this trip, we will be forever greatful because this is a once in a life time experience we will never forget.

story:
Malawi's Lost Years, 1964-1994 

"Bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje" He who gives the blow forgets; he who carries the scar remembers. (Haitian Creole proverb)

BACKGROUND

Project summary

Malawi's Lost Years, 1964-94

"Bay kou bliye, pote mak sonje"

He who gives the blow forgets; he who carries the scar remembers.

(Haitian Creole proverb)

  2014 is the 50th year since independence from British colonial rule and the 20th year since the dictator, Dr Hastings Kamuzu Banda and his cronies were forced from power by a democratic vote following a popular uprising and mounting international pressure. For 30 years, from 1964 to1994, Malawi suffered under the iron fist of Dr Banda. No opposition or even criticism was tolerated and his rule was marked by arbitrary arrest, detention, torture, political murder and a reign of terror that enforced silent suffering on the people and forced many to flee into exile.

  The Banda regime created its version of history that exalted the dictator and erased this dark side of his rule. Here we present the untold stories which represent the missing link in the continuum of Malawi’s history. Doug and Kapote have been interviewing survivors who suffered under the regime and want to publish their stories.

WHO ARE WE?

Doug Miller – Originally from Ottawa, Doug was teaching in Malawi from 1968 to 1972 when he married Nellie Saka, a fellow teacher from Kasungu. He was CUSO Country Director for a year in 1975-76 but had to flee into exile because the level of oppression had become unsafe and unbearable. There, he became active in LESOMA, the Socialist League of Malawi. In the early 1990's, Doug and Nellie were deeply involved in the Malawi Action Committee and the Canadian Friends of Malawi, advocating and lobbying governments and international organisations to bring about an end of the Banda dictatorship. Archibald Kapote Mwakasungura – Kapote was a student activist who fled Malawi for exile in Tanzania in October 1964 as Kamuzu Banda installed his brutal dictatorship. Kapote lived and studied in Dar es Salaam and later taught at the Mzumbe Institute of Development Management in Morogoro. In 1974 he was a founding member of LESOMA along with his colleagues, John Jando Nkhwazi, William Chisausau Msowoya and Mundu Mwambetania. LESOMA quickly became the most effective political opposition of Malawians in exile and Kapote served as the highly respected Secretary General until the democratic dispensation in 1992-94 ended the Banda tyranny. He then became a key player in shaping the democratic transition and the constitution of the second republic and served briefly as High Commissioner to Zimbabwe from 1995 to April 1998. He is now retired, and although almost blind, is active in Karonga as Chairman of the Cultural and Museum Centre of Karonga and Group Village Headman of Kasoba.

WHY IS THIS BOOK IMPORTANT?

This history is fast disappearing as the participants age and their numbers dwindle. We are trying to find as many of these survivors as possible and let them tell their version of life under Banda, from the nationalist struggle through independence to the implantation of the dictatorship and now under a twisted and distorted democracy.

  We are indignant that the current leadership of Malawi has been rehabilitating Banda's image and honouring him despite the well documented reports of the regime's atrocities and abuse of human rights. We know many people who suffered or died at Banda's hands and feel it important to redress this unfair revision of Malawian history. This rehabilitation of Kamuzu Banda and his record is wiping out some 30 years of history as though it had never happened. The Malawi people continue to suffer in absolute poverty and in greater numbers than ever, while the political leadership, mostly dynastic inheritors follow in Banda's footsteps. The culture of impunity, the high-level corruption, and official amnesia is what Banda used to make himself fabulously wealthy and is the pattern emulated by today's leaders. We feel it is imperative to speak out to remove this atrocious blind spot.

OBJECTIVE

Our goal is to produce a small affordable paperback book to disseminate as widely as possible both inside and outside Malawi. By publishing it locally in Malawi, we can keep the cost low, so that poorer Malawians can afford to buy it. For $7000, we can produce 3,000 copies for sale throughout the country. With $15000, we plan to distribute a copy to every secondary and post-secondary school library in the country.

Costs include editing, layout, printing, and distribution as well as perks for contributors.

THE IMPACT

Every country and government has dirt swept under the carpet. Malawi is a small and little known country, but the crimes committed against its people by the brutal Banda dictatorship are a part of our shared human history. The message of this book project is universal. It is about what happens when governments turn on their own people and commit atrocities with impunity. These are not easy stories to tell and people in power do not want them to be made public.

We are looking for the support of principled people who agree with us that these histories must be openly faced, discussed and acknowledged as lessons for the future. Sweeping abuse under the carpet does not bring freedom and justice, it leaves the house very dirty.

This is not about charity. It is a question of solidarity. Your support will further the struggle to tell the stories of how human rights abuse affect the lives of real people. Your contribution to exposing the truth is part of the calling to account of leaders who hide behind their authority and mistreat the people they are supposed to protect and develop. We look forward to your support.

WHAT IS IN IT FOR YOU?

Besides the perks, you will be learning about and understanding the roots of injustice and in so doing help inform future generations about the need to protect human rights and bring about social justice. You can be part of this process.

Thank you for your solidarity

Doug and Kapote

The authors

story:
Toronto – On March 20th 2014, Carlie Ritch, a.k.a. Mizz Barbie Bitch, will be registering as a candidate for the office of mayor of Toronto, at 11:30 am at Toronto City Hall.

Ms. Ritch’s experience as a professional Dominatrix will finally bring much needed discipline and order to a government institution that has been clearly witnessed by many Torontonians as dysfunctional and out of touch.

“The last four years, Toronto has become a lost city with a council that’s bent on focusing on the antics of a mayor who has no power and is out of control,” says Ms. Ritch. “As mayor I intent to whip this city into shape and make sure everyone knows their roles and duties to get this city back to what it once was, a world class meeting place.”

As mayor, Ms. Ritch is commited to revamping the Gardner, and placing the Metronome in place of the Canadian Malting site to create Canadas first Music City.

She is also promising to bring pride back to Pride; advocate term lengths for politicians; ensure nutritional programs for children, not only continue but are made a priority; local job creation programs are developed; support cleaner energy initiatives, together with expanding transit and public space.

With seven months remaining in the campaign for office of Mayor, many have staked claim for the position, but only one person will master the win.  On October 27th 2014, vote for Carlie Ritch.

Contact the Carlie Ritch / Ms. Bitch Campaign at:

voteritch@hotmail.com / 647 – 996-7465

story:
Short Summary

  • The Appalachian Women's Museum is a non-profit 501 (c) (3)
  • Our Mission: to gather, preserve, and share the stories of the women of Southern Appalachia.
  • Our Vision: To become a recognized and respected home for the history of the women of Southern Appalachia that is a resource and repository for the artifacts, archives, and other research materials that tells the stories of these women and of the people whose lives they touched.
  • Our Current Status:
  • We recently signed a 5-year lease on the Monteith Farmstead with the Town of Dillsboro. The house, built in 1908, is a wonderful example of vernacular architecture, and was placed on the National Register in 2008. It was also home to two extraordinary women: Edna and Edith Monteith. Their lives inspired a committed group in Dillsboro to create a museum that chronicled the accomplishments of Southern Appalachian women. According to our lease, if we show substantial progress either through fundraising efforts or through restoration of the Monteith Farmstead, the Town will deed our organization the house.

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $16,000 to restore the roof on the Monteith Farmstead. This is just the first of many steps that we need to take to completely restore the house. If we don't raise the $16,000 with this campaign, we will continue to try to raise the money through other means until we reach this first goal. Regardless, your money will go to our restoration project. You will get the satisfaction of knowing that you contributed to this enormously important educational project.

The Impact

  • Your support will help us continue to succeed. In the past, we have received the following grants: Blue Ridge National Heritage Area Grant, North Carolina Steadman Incentive Grant, and the Appalachian Regional Commission.
  • We have community partnerships with the Town of Dillsboro, the Dillsboro Merchants Association, the Community Gardeners group, the Watershed Association of the Tuckasegee River, and Western Carolina University.
  • Your support will help us to expand the educational opportunities of this region and to support our growing heritage tourism economy.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word using social media.
  • Follow our progress on Facebook and the web.

story:
My name is Jerry McNeely

 The name of my business is "McNeely's House of Music". I've been a musician almost my whole life. I started at the age of 8 years old. I started taking a music class in elementary school and it was something that I was truly passionate about right off. But my music class was only one hour a week because the school system didn't think it was important enough to spend more money on it. It wasn't enough time to really learn anything. And its not like I had an option to take a drum class after school either, because not a lot of people can spend the kind of money it takes to have enough equipment to start a class. I would drive my sisters crazy because I would bang on the snare drum all day as loud as I could,( dreaming of one day becoming a rock star ) so eventually they would make me quit playing! Skip forward over 20 years and it hasn't changed much. If your in elementary school you don't get but one hour once a week and that's it. Its a shame. Most kids love to learn and play music at that age. There creativity bone is going crazy. I handed my youngest daughter a set of sticks one night to play on some drums and she was able to play a simple drum beat within minutes, just like i did at her age. Its amazing to me, that kids can be so tuned-in just by watching me for a couple minutes. So I'm here to do something about it. I'm working toward an after school program for children of all ages to come learn and most importantly have fun. I want to help inspire the next generations great musicians. I want to help these kids be apart of something they will never forget.

Now just because I love to play and have a real passion to do this, doesn't automatically make me qualified to teach a class, but my experience does. I've got over 20 years of music in my pocket , plus 5 years of teaching. I've never held a class before but ive taught kids over the years at my home, plus we have to start some where in life, right? There is only two things I've ever been great at, one is I'm a knowledgeable musician, two is I'm great with kids. I have the patience to sit down with a child and get them to understand what it is I'm teaching them. I'm a motivated man with a mission to " Help keep music Alive". But as great as it all sounds I can't do it by myself, I need help getting started. I do have some equipment but nowhere near enough. Its going to take quite a bit of money to get all the instruments and accessories we are going to need. Plus I do have a wife and three kids so I can't pour all my own money into it, although I will most likely do so. I don't know if coming to this site will even help me get my goal but if I'm able to raise even $500 then it will have been worth it. What ever help we get( No matter how great or small of donations we achieve ) will go towards equipment needed to teach a class of at least ten. I know we can do this people. If I can volunteer my time and money then im sure we can do great things for these kids.So, if you can find it in your heart to take a chance and help what little bit you can, it will not only bring a smile to a child's face, but possibly change their lives. Just remember, it might be my dream but it is a child's happiness that we are really giving here. Thank You for reading this and God Bless. If you have any questions leave me a comment or just email me @

jrmcneely31@gmail.com or

mcneelyshouseofmusic@gmail.com
